the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p:
--I will give $20 reward for the return of my Negro man, "Washington," who left my house, in the lower end of Henrico county, on the morning of the 17th ult., without leave or provocation.
Washington is about 5 feet 8 or 9 inches high, very black, about twenty years old, and has very white teeth, and smiles very pleasantly when spoken to. He will probably have a forged pass is his possession, as he can read and write.
I will give the above reward for his return to me at my house, or if he is secured in jail so that I can get him.

The Portable Grate is both "cheerful and sensible." Stoves sold by main years past repaired, or taken in exchange for new. Second-hand Stoves sold cheap.
Also — Plumbing, Gas-Fitting and Tin Work done with dispatch, at the "Governor Street Stove store." George Starrett, Belvin's Row.

argument.p: from the South--correspondence between Judge Robertson and the Governor of Alabama-- the Marine seizure at Savannah — no more troops to be ordered to the Capital-- Washington dispatches — Pensacola affairs, &c., &c.

div4.p: A Lone Star meeting was called at Crescent City, Refugio county, Texas, a few days since, and was about to adjourn for want of a leader, when, all at once, appeared a Miss Adams with a San Jacinto banner in her hand, and said:

q.p:
"Sons of Texas, in the name of my sex, for the freedom of the South, I present you the coat of arms of Texas.
Protect it; we shall stand at your side!"

div4.p:
A meeting was recently held at Holly Springs' Miss., for the purpose of raising means to equip a company of volunteers, and $5,000 was subscribed on the spot.
One of the subscribers was a lady, who stated that her husband and two sons were ready to fight, and that her three daughters would make cartridges, lint and clothing for the soldiers.

div4.head: Correspondence between Judge Robertson, Commissioner from Virginia, and Gov. Moore, of Alabama.

opener.salute: To His Excellency, the Governor of Alabama:

div5.p: Looking with deep concern at the menacing attitude in which the seceded States and the Government at Washington stand towards each other, the State of Virginia appears to both parties to abstain from all acts of a hostile tendency, until a farther effort shall be made to terminate existing differences, by an honorable and peaceful adjustment.

I avail myself of the earliest moment to transmit to your Excellency the resolutions of the General Assembly of Virginia, adopted with that view, and commissioning me to convey their friendly mediation to yourself, and the authorities of the seceded States.
The day for the meeting of the proposed Commissioners at Washington, you will perceive, is at hand.
This must be my apology for asking as early a reply as may consist with your convenience.
It will afford me much pleasure to give, if desired, any further explanations in my power, touching the objects of my mission, or the views and wishes of the State I have the honor to represent.

div4.head:
Executive Department,
Montgomery, Ala., Feb. 3d, 1861.

opener.salute: To Hon. John Robertson, Commissioner from the state of Virginia:

div4.p:
I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of this date, with the preamble and resolutions adopted by the General Assembly of Virginia, January 19th, 1861.
As Chief Magistrate of the State of Alabama, I extend to you a cordial welcome to the seat of Government, as Commissioner from the Commonwealth of Virginia.

From your letter, and the resolutions referred to. I understand that Ex-President John Tyler has been appointed a "Commissioner to the President of the United States," and yourself "to South Carolina and the other States that have seceded, or shall secede, with instructions respectfully to request the President of the United States, and the authorities of such States, to abstain pending the proceedings contemplated by the action of the General Assembly, from any and all acts calculated to produce a collision of arms between the States and the Government of the United States."

After tendering to the State of Virginia, through you, my thanks for the friendly mediation contemplated by the resolutions of her General Assembly, it gives me much pleasure to state, that Alabama, in her act of Secession, and in occupying the forts and arsenals within her limits, intended no hostility to the Federal Government.
Her sole object has been to protect her rights, interests and honor, without disturbing (if possible) her peaceful relations with the Federal Government.--This, I feel assured, will continue to be the policy of the State, unless the Federal authorities should, by some hostile act or demonstration, make it necessary to adopt a different course for her protection, and the protection of the other States that have seceded, or may secede.

Whilst I feel authorized to assure you that Alabama will do nothing intended to produce a collision of arms between the Federal Government and herself, I am equally certain that it is her firm determination to resist, at all and every hazard, any attempt at coercion.

Having no power to appoint delegates to the proposed Convention at Washington, the resolutions of the General Assembly of Virginia will be immediately transmitted to the Legislature of this State, where, I have no doubt, they will receive that respectful consideration the high and friendly source from which they come entitles them to.
Candor, however, compels me to say, that I do not feel authorized to indulge the least hope that concessions will be made affording such guarantees as the seceding States can or will accept.

Being satisfied that the State from which emanated the resolutions of '98 and '99 is as determined to maintain her constitutional rights as the seceding States, I do not entertain a doubt that she will be found co-operating with them, when she is convinced that those rights cannot be secured in the Federal Union.
For the courteous and dignified manner in which you have made known the object of your mission, you will please accept my thanks.
Judge Robertson, in reply to an invitation of the Alabama Legislature to address it on the subject of his mission, wrote the following letter:

opener.salute: To Messrs. Horn, McIntyre, Ligon, of the Senate, and Messrs. Walker, Hubbard, and Lyon, of the House of Representatives:

div5.p: I am truly grateful for the honor conferred on me by the resolutions of the General Assembly of Alabama, inviting me to address them in the Hall of the House of Representatives, and sincerely regret that I do not feel at liberty to attempt a compliance with their flattering request.

The mission entrusted to me, by the State of Virginia, is one of conciliation and peace.
It is of a very definite character, bringing me into special communication with the Executive authorities of the States to which I am commissioned.

It has already been made known to his Excellency Governor Moore, and, I am happy to say, has been met and promoted by him in the same spirit in which it was conceived.
The propositions of Virginia relative to the appointment of Commissioners to Washington , now before your Legislature, are not within its scope.
They have been submitted to the action of the Legislature and Executive Departments.
Were I to address your honorable body on that subject, or generally on the great questions which agitate the States recently composing the Federal Union, the very fact that I held a commission from my honored State of the character described, would possibly give to my humble views an influence and effect they would not otherwise be entitled to command.
They would probably be regarded as the sentiments of Virginia, and thus, in some degree, attach a responsibility to her beyond the limits of my authority to impose, and which she might not be willing to assume.

Under these impressions I shall stand, I trust, readily excused for denying myself the pleasure of accepting an invitation so complimentary to myself personally, and to the State which I have the honor to represent.
Receive, gentlemen, for yourselves, and for the Senate and House of Representatives of Alabama, assurances of my high respect.

div4.head: The Marine seizure at Savannah.
div4.p:
The Savannah Republican thus describes the coup-de-etat by which Gov. Brown, of Georgia, accomplished such a speedy solution of a "knotty" question.
As is known, a demand was made by the Governor of Georgia upon the Governor of New York for the immediate delivery of the property unlawfully taken into possession by the police of New York city.
Up to Wednesday last no response had been received to this demand, whereupon Gov. Brown addressed the following order to Col. Henry R. Jackson, one of his Aids, in the city of Savannah:

div5.head:
Executive Department,
Milledgeville,
February 5th, 1861.

opener.salute: Col. H. R. Jackson, A. D. C.

div5.p:
I have demanded of the Governor of New York the prompt delivery to my agent, for D. C. Hodgkins, & Sons, citizens of this State, of their guns, seized by the police of New York on board the Monticello, and deposited in the arsenal of that State.
The demand has been delivered to him; he has had a reasonable time and has made no reply.
I am determined to protect the persons ject to my order, every ship now in the harbor at Savannah belonging to citizens of the State of New York.

When the property of which our citizens have been robbed, is returned to them, the ships will be delivered to the citizens of New York who own them.
I am, sir, your ob't serv't,

div4.p: This order was quietly executed yesterday by Col. Lawton, who seized and took into his possession the following vessels, now lying at our wharf, the property of citizens of New York:
Brig W. R. Kerby, Capt. Barstow, with coal, consigned to master.
Bark Adjuster, Capt. Ewell, consigned to master.
Brig Golden Lead, Capt. Johnson, consigned to R. Habersham & Son, and loading for Aspinwall.
Schooner Julia A. Hallock, Capt. Pedrick, consigned to master.
Bark D. Colden Murray, Capt. Murray, consigned to Muller & Michels, and loading for Rotterdam.

These vessels are now in the possession of the State, and will be held until the Governor of New York shall have ordered a restoration of the arms taken from the Monticello.
They are valued, we learn, at $50,000. Small detachments from the PhŒnix Riflemen, Capt. Gordon, that corps now being on alarm duty, were placed on board each of the vessels as a guard, though strict orders have been given that in no case shall the officers, crew or cargoes be molested.
The vessels will be allowed to discharge and load without interruption, though they will not be permitted to leave the port.

The effect of this seizure remains to be seen.
The two States have it in their power to do a vast amount of harm to the citizens of each other, but we hope moderation will prevail, and that all cause of disturbance will be promptly allayed by the Governor of New York, who has full power to restore matters to their original position.
No more troops to be ordered to the Capital.

Gen. Scott has written a letter to the officers of the Scott Life Guard, of New York, who tendered their services for the defence of the capital.
It is as follows:

opener.salute: To Captain Ward, Lieutenants MacGregor, Jameson and Peel., and my friends of the Scott Life Guard:

div5.p: Please accept my thanks for the personal kindness to myself that dictates the expression of your desire to be at my side in this crisis of our country.

The Government does not contemplate calling any troops here other than the District militia and some detachments of regular troops, and it is desired by the friends of peace that no organized societies or clubs, even without arms, shall make their appearance here until the tranquility of the public mind be restored.
I cannot counsel an exception in your favor, much as I should value your faithful services.
With the affectionate regard of an old brother soldier, I remain, truly yours,

div4.head: The Army of Louisiana.
div4.p:
The bill reported in the Convention yesterday by Mr. Richard Taylor, the only son of the immortal "old Zack," creating two regiments of a thousand men each, as the nuclei us of an army for this State, received the unanimous assent of that body.
The bill was well digested and prepared, and Mr. Taylor's remarks in explanation of its provisions were marked by that good sense, that clearness of statement and sound judgment characteristic of this worthy son of a gallant, sagacious and patriotic father.
This bill dispenses with the services of our volunteers for the hard work and drudgery of the service.
It will be enough for that gallant corps to hold itself ready for the defense of the State in the event of war.--But, in the meantime, for the occupation and defence of the forts which have fallen into the hands of the State, a more stable and better organized force is required.--N. O. Delta.

div4.head: Washington dispatches.
div4.p:
It is not the intention of General Cass to leave Washington before the 6th of March, being determined to see President Lincoln inaugurated.
He says it is the last ceremony of the kind he shall probably ever see.

It is announced that ex-Secretary Floyd will be here in a couple of weeks to demand an immediate trial of the indictment which has been found against him by the Grand Jury.
He charges that the indictment is a malicious prosecution, the procurement of ex-Secretary Thompson, aided by the Administration.
General Weightman yesterday refused a commission to Captain Schaeffer, of the National Rifles, under a singular state of circumstances, which has caused some excitement in military circles.

Captain Schaeffer was notified to call and receive his commission, and reported himself at the War Department.
Previous to issuing it a series of questions were propounded to the Captain, by General Weightman, among which was the question:

p.q: "If Maryland should secede, and you were ordered by your military superiors to make war on her, what would you do?"

div4.p: Captain S. frankly responded to the inquiry:

p.q: "Maryland, sir, is my native State--if she should ever unfortunately be placed as you suppose, I would resign my commission."

div4.p: "Then you cannot receive it," responded General Weightman, "it will be returned to the Secretary of War."

Secretary Holt has sustained the decision of General Weightman, and the matter is now before the President for his revision.
Captain Schaeffer has stated to the President that "he and his company are ready to repel any invasion of the District of Columbia from any quarter, but would say no more."

div4.head: Pensacola affairs.
div4.p:
A letter to the Montgomery (Ala.) Mail, from Fort Barraneas, Pensacola harbor, Florida, and dated February 3d, says that everything is quiet at that point.
Everything was then in state quo. The U. S. steamer Wyandotte was still lying under the guns of Fort Pickens.
Her commander, Capt. Berryman, is a Virginia, as is also the surgeon, Dr. Garnet.
The latter has sent on his resignation, and the former says he will resign as soon as the Old Dominion secedes.

Lieut. Slemmer had paid several visits to Col. Lomax, of the State troops.
The former said he had been expecting an attack for some time.
The Colonel replied: "You would not have been disappointed if I had been in command."
The State troops are becoming dissatisfied with the inactivity which prevails around Pensacola, and the Mississippi Regiment was to have left on Monday last.

div4.head: Laying in supplies.
div4.p:
The Cincinnati Enquirer states that Major Hayne, of the South Carolina army, and brother to Colonel Hayne, bearer of dispatches to Washington from Gov. Pickens, was in the former city and in St. Louis last week, where he purchased and shipped for home 47,000 bbls. of pork, 4,000 casks of bacon, and several thousand bushels of corn for the use of the Carolinian army.
These supplies were forwarded via the Nashville and Chattanooga Road.

div3.head: Recoinage of cents.
div3.p: --The following official notice has been issued by the Director of the Philadelphia Mint:

div4.head: Mint of the United States,
div4.p: The regulations heretofore prescribed, authorizing the payment of the expenses of transportation of the old copper cents of the United States to the Mint, will cease on and after the 20th instant.

The cents of the new issue will be paid out at the Mint in exchange for any of the gold and silver coins of the United States, and also in exchange for the old copper coins if delivered at the Mint.
The reasonable expenses of transportation of the new cents, in sums not less than $20 thus exchanged, will be paid by the Mint as heretofore.

div3.head: Railroad Appointments.
div3.p: --The Cincinnati Gazette of Tuesday says:

q.p: George W. Fulton, Railroad Editor of the Cincinnati Commercial, was yesterday appointed Superintendent of the Covington and Lexington Railroad. Mr. Fulton has had considerable experience as a Railroad Superintendent, and was strongly recommended to the position by some of the most prominent railroad men in the State.

div3.head: Murder' in St. Louis.
div3.p:
--Mrs. Anna Maria Durmae, a young German woman, well known in St. Louis, was murdered and robbed in that city on Thursday last, her body being found the succeeding day, lying nearly nude in a muddy hollow in the outskirts of the city.
The victim was of a highly respectable family, and though remarkably well educated, speaking several modern and one or two ancient languages, had yet acquired habits of inebriety, which she attributed to the desertion of her husband and the death of her only child.
She was in the receipt of a handsome income, and wore about her person a considerable sum of money, which was probably the temptation to her murder.

div3.head: Awkward expose.
div3.p:
--A decidedly rich expose has recently taken place, which will not increase the high reputation of that once fashionable "artist," the late Count D'Orsay,who enjoyed a great name as a painter and sculptor.
It seems that he employed two >aids

div3.head:
Fort Sumter.
South Carolina's demand.
the President's reply.
div3.p: The following is the reply of the President to the demand of Col. Hayne that Fort Sumter shall be delivered up to South Carolina:

div4.head: The final reply to Mr. Hayne.
div4.p: --The President of the United States has received your letter of the 31st ultimo, and has charged me with the duty of replying thereto.
In the communication addressed to the President by Governor Pickens, under date of the 12th of January, and which accompanies yours now before me, his Excellency says:

q.p:
"I have determined to send to you Hon. I. W. Hayne, the Attorney General of the State of South Carolina, and have instructed him to demand the surrender of Fort Sumter, in the harbor of Charleston, to the constituted authorities of the State of South Carolina.
The demand I have made of Major Anderson, and which I now make of you, is suggested because of my earnest desire to avoid the bloodshed which a persistence in your attempt to retain the possession of that fort will cause and which will be unavailing to secure to you that possession, but induce a calamity most deeply to be deplored."

div4.p: The character of the demand thus authorized to be made, appears, under the influence I presume of the correspondence with the Senators to which you refer, to have been modified by subsequent instructions of his Excellency, dated the 26th, and received by yourself on the 30th of January, in which he says:

q.p: "If it be so that Fort Sumter is held as property, then as property the rights, whatever they may be, of the United States, can be ascertained; and for the satisfaction of these rights the pledge of the State of South Carolina you are authorized to give."

div4.p: The full scope and precise purport of your instructions, as thus modified, you have expressed in the following words:

q.p: "I do not some as a military man to demand the surrender of a fortress, but as the legal officer of the State--its Attorney General--to claim for the State the exercise of its undoubted right of eminent domain, and to pledge the State to make good all injury to the rights of property which arise from the exercise of the claim."

div4.p: And lest this explicit language should not sufficiently define your position, you add:

q.p: "The proposition now is that her (South Carolina's) law officer should, under the authority of the Governor and his Council, distinctly pledge the faith of South Carolina to make such compensation, in regard to Fort Sumter and its appurtenances and contents, to the full extent of the money value of the property of the United States delivered over to the authorities of South Carolina by your command."

div4.p: You then adopt his Excellency's train of thought upon the subject so far as to suggest that the possession of Fort Sumter by the U. States, "if continued long enough, must lead to collision," and that "an attack upon it would scarcely improve it as property, whatever the result, and, if captured, it would no longer be the subject of account. "

The proposal, then, now presented to the President, is simply an offer on the part of S. Carolina to buy Fort Sumter and contents as property of the United States, sustained by a declaration in effect, that if she is not permitted to make the purchase, she will seize the fort by force of arms.
As the initiation of a negotiation for the transfer of property between friendly Governments, this proposal impresses the President as having assumed a most unusual form.
He has, however, investigated the claim on which it professes to be based, apart from the declaration that accompanies it. And it may be here remarked that much stress has been laid upon the employment of the words "property" and "public property " by the President in his several messages.
These are the most comprehensive terms which can be used in such a connection, and, surely, when referring to a fort or any other public establishment, they embraced the entire and undivided interest of the Government therein.

The title of the United States to Fort Sumter is complete and incontestable.
Were its interest in this property purely proprietary, in the ordinary acceptation of the term, it might probably be subjected to the exercise of the right of eminent domain; but it has also political relations to it of a much higher and more imposing character than those of mere proprietorship.
It has absolute jurisdiction over the fort and the soil on which it stands.
This jurisdiction consists in the authority to "exercise exclusive legislation" over the property referred to, and is therefore clearly incompatible with the claim of eminent domain now insisted upon by South Carolina.
This authority was not derived from any questionable, revolutionary source, but from the peaceful cession of South Carolina herself, acting through her Legislature, under a provision of the Constitution of the United States. South Carolina can no more assert the right of eminent domain over Fort Sumter than Maryland can assert it over the District of Columbia.--The political and proprietary rights of the U. States in either case rest upon precisely the same ground.

The President, however, is relieved from the necessity of further pursuing this inquiry by the fact that, whatever may be the claim of South Carolina to this fort, he has no constitutional power to cede or surrender it. The property of the United States has been acquired by force of public law and can only be disposed of under the same solemn sanctions.
The President, as the head of the Executive branch of the Government only, can no more sell and transfer Fort Sumter to South Carolina than he can sell and convey the Capitol of the United States to Maryland, or to any other State or individual seeking to possess it. His Excellency the Governor, is too familiar with the Constitution of the United States, and with the limitations upon the powers of the Chief Magistrate of the Government it has established, not to appreciate at once the soundness of this legal proposition.

The question of reinforcing Fort Sumter is so fully disposed of in my letter to Senator Slidell and others, under date of the 22d of January--a copy of which accompanies this — that its discussion will not now be renewed.
I then said:

q.p: "At the present moment it is not deemed necessary to reinforce Major Anderson, because he makes no such request.--Should his safety, however, require reinforcements, every effort will be made to supply them."

div4.p:
can add nothing to the explicitness of this language, which still applies to the existing status.
The right to send forward reinforcements, when in the judgment of the President the safety of the garrison requires them, rests on the same unquestionable foundation as the right to occupy the fortress itself.

Fort Sumter is in itself a military post, and nothing else; and it would seem that not so much the fact as the purpose of its use should give to it a hostile or friendly character.
This fortress is now held by the Government of the United States, for the same objects for which it has been held from the completion of its construction.
These are national and defensive; and were a public enemy now to attempt the capture of Charleston or the destruction of the commerce of its harbor, the whole force of the batteries of this fortress would be at once exerted for their protection.
How the presence of a small garrison, actuated by such a spirit as this, can compromise the dignity or honor of South Carolina, or become a source of irritation to her people, the President is at a loss to understand.
The attitude of that garrison, as has been often declared, is neither menacing nor defiant, nor unfriendly.
It is acting under orders to stand strictly on the defensive, and the Government and people of South Carolina must well know that they can never receive aught but shelter from its guns, unless, in the absence of all provocation they should assault it, and seek its destruction.
The intent with which this fortress is held by the President is truthfully stated by Senator Davis and others, in their letter to yourself of the 15th January, in which they say:

q.p: "It is not held with any hostile or unfriendly purpose towards your State, but merely as property of the United States, which the President deems it his duty to protect and preserve. "

div4.p: In the letter of Senator Davis and others to yourself, under date of the 15th ultimo, they say:

q.p: "We, therefore, think it especially due from South Carolina to our States--to say nothing of other slaveholding States--that she should, as far as she can consistently with her honor, avoid initiating hostilities between her and the United States or any other Power;"

div4.p:
and you now yourself give to the President the gratifying assurance that South Carolina has every disposition to preserve the public peace; and, since he is himself sincerely animated by the same desire, it would seem that this common and patriotic object must be of certain attainment.
It is difficult, however, to reconcile with this assurance the declaration on your part that "it is a consideration of her (South Carolina's) own dignity as a sovereign, and the safety of her people, which prompts her to demand that this property should not longer be used as a military post by a Government she no longer acknowledges," and the thought you so constantly present that this occupation must lead to a collision of arms and the prevalence of civil war.

If the announcement, so repeatedly made, of the President's pacific purposes in continuing the occupation of Fort Sumter until the question shall have been settled by competent au view of the circumstances which have so severely tried it, be not accepted as a satisfactory pledge of the peaceful policy of this Administration towards South Carolina, then it may be safely affirmed that neither language nor conduct can possibly furnish one.
If, with all the multiplied proofs which exist of the President's anxiety for peace, and of the earnestness with which he has pursued it, the authorities of that State shall assault Fort Sumter, and peril the lives of the handful of brave and loyal men shut up within its walls, and thus plunge our common country into the horrors of civil war, then upon them and those they represent must rest the responsibility.

closer.signed: Hon. I. W. Hayne, Attorney General of the State of South Carolina.

div4.head: Col. Hayne's Rejoinder.
div4.p:
Under date of February 7th, Col. Hayne rejoined.
This document was not transmitted to Congress by the President, but a copy has been furnished for publication.
The Colonel is bold and defiant.
He concludes as follows:

q.p:
"It was no part of my mission to discuss the political relations of the United States Government to anything within the territorial limits of South Carolina. South Carolina claims to have dissolved all political connection with your Government, and to have destroyed all political relations of your Government with everything within her borders.
She is unquestionably at this moment de facte a separate and independent Government, exercising complete sovereignty over every foot of her soil except Fort Sumter.
Now that the intention is avowed to hold this place as a military post, with a claim of exclusive jurisdiction on the part of a Government foreign to South Carolina, it will be for the authorities to determine what is the course proper to be pursued.
It is then to ignore the fact that South Carolina is to yours a foreign Government.
And how, with this patent fact before you, you can consider the continued occupation of the fort in her harbor a pacific measure and a parcel of a peaceful policy, passes, certainly, my comprehension.

"You say that the fort is garrisoned for our protection, and is held for the same purpose for which it has been ever held since its construction.
Are you not aware that to hold in the territory of a foreign power a fortress against her will, avowedly for the purpose of protecting her citizens, is perhaps the highest insult which one Government can offer to another?
But Fort Sumter was never garrisoned at all until South Carolina had dissolved her connection with your Government.
This garrison entered in the night, with every circumstance of secrecy, after spiking the guns and burning the gun-carriages, and cutting down the flag-staff of an adjacent fort, which was then abandoned.
South Carolina had not taken Fort Sumter into her own possession only because of her misplaced confidence in a Government which deceived her. A fortress occupied under the circumstances above stated, is considered not only as no cause of irritation.
but you represent it as held for our protection.
Your Excellency's Secretary has indulged in irony on a very grave subject.
As to the responsibility for consequences, if indeed it does rest on us, I can assure your Excellency we are happily unconscious of the fact.

closer.salute: "With considerations of high regard, I am, very respectfully,

div3.head: Horrible.
div3.p:
--In Philadelphia, a day or two since, the police of the First District had their attention directed to a shocking scene in a house in Morgan court, in the Second Ward.
A woman was lying dead in bed, and her drunken husband was lying beside her. An officer who went into the house roused up the husband, and told him that his wife was dead.
The brute replied that she was only dead drunk, and he struck the corpse in the face with his fist.
He was arrested and taken to the station-house.

div3.head: Another murder by Montgomery's Band.
div3.p:
--The St. Louis Republican, of the 7th, gives the particulars, obtained from private sources, of the murder of Mr. Carey, an inoffensive citizen of Brownsville, Missouri, committed on the road to Knob Noster.
Mr. Carey formerly resided in Kansas, where he took sides strongly against Montgomery, and his murder is attributed to a member of that desperado's gang.

div3.head: Death from chloroform.
div3.p:
--Jas. D. Houston, a youth of about sixteen years of age, engaged in business in Tallahassee, Fla., was found dead in his room on Thursday morning ast, with a vial of chloroform in his hand, his death being evidently in consequence of his having inhaled too much of the fatal dose.
He had been suffering with toothache and was using the chloroform to relieve the pain.

div3.head: A Federal head in the Basket.
div3.p:
--Judge Jordan, Postmaster at Pensacola, Fla., (Confederated States of North America,) has been guillotined by Postmaster-General Holt.
The act, says the Observer of that town, was performed by "the despotic incumbent of the Post-Office Department of the Northern Republic."

has increased in size more than three-fold since the close of the Revolutionary War. The United States have a territorial extent nearly ten times as large as that of Great Britain and France combined.
The American Republic is one-sixth only less in extent than the area covered by the fifty-nine empires, States and republics of Europe.

div3.head: Another large Company for the West.
div3.p:
--A party of over sixty boys and girls, varying in age from six to seven years, a large proportion orphan and destitute, left New York on Tuesday, under the charge of Mr. H. Friedgen, of the Children's Aid Society.
A more interesting company, it is said, has never been sent to the West under the auspices of this institution.

div3.head: Failure of an Oil well.
div3.p:
--The oil well belonging to Mr. Dutton, near Parkersburg, Va., which had been yielding about fifty barrels of oil per day, has entirely failed.
It was caused by the sinking of another well a short distance from it.

div3.head: Charleston Races
div3.p:
--Third Day.--The Governor, and many officers of the State, were present.
The race was for a Jockey Club purse, of $500--two mile heats.
It was won by Fanny Washington over Oysterman, Corinne, and John Linton.
Time: 3.49¾; 3.48

div3.head: Fatal accident.
div3.p: --On Saturday last, Mr. Jefferson Goslin, of Alexandria, Va., whilst cutting wood in Fairfax county, accidentally cut himself with an axe, and was injured so severely that in a short time he died from the effects of the wound.

div3.head: Affray.
div3.p:
--In Greenville county, Va., on the 5th inst., James Childes, formerly an inmate of the State prison, was shot and mortally wounded by John Morris.
The difficulty originated in a bar-room dispute.

div3.head: Murder.
div3.p: --Geo. Sawyer, Sr., a planter near Lexington, S. C., was waylaid and murdered, by two of his negroes, on the 1st inst. One of the murderers was sentenced to death, and the other, a boy of weak mind, to receive 300 lashes.

An old soaker being found in the gutter one rainy night, the water making a clear breach over him from head to foot, was asked by a passer what he was doing there, "Oh," said he, "I agreed to meet a man here."

These new Machines, for Cards, Bill-Heads, Small Circulars, Labels, &c., are capable of turning off 1,500 impressions per hour, thereby enabling the patrons of this establishment to obtain this description of work at the shortest possible notice.

Duval's Lustrale is by far the best Hair Dressing now in use. It is manufactured with care from the best materials, no pains being spared to make it pre-eminently worthy the patronage of the public.
A single trial will prove all we say for it. Manufactured and sold, wholesale and retail, by J. P. Duval, corner Main and 14th sts., and sold by Druggists generally.

div3.head: Landreth's Garden Seed — New crop.
div3.p:
--We have now in store a complete assortment of Garden Seed, early and late Peas, Six Weeks and Valentine Shape Beans — all of which are warranted fresh and genuine.
Descriptive catalogues for gratuitous distribution.

div3.head: City Council.
div3.p:
--The monthly meeting of the City Council was held last evening.
Present: Messrs. Saunders, Grattan, Denton, Haskins, Richardson, Griffin, Greanor, Scott, Talbott, Burr, Howison, Hill, Anderson, and Glazebrook.

Mr. Grattan, from the Committee of Finance, submitted an ordinance imposing taxes for the next fiscal year, and the Auditor's statements of the receipts and disbursements for the eleven months ending the 1st February, 1861, and estimate of receipts and disbursements for the next fiscal year.
The amount received into the treasury from the 1st of March, 1860, to the 1st of February, 1861, including the balance on hand at the commencement of this period, was $613,951.77; and the whole amount of disbursements during the same period was $604,739.85; leaving in the treasury on the 1st of February, 1861, $9,194.92.

The Auditor's estimated receipts for the next fiscal year from all sources except taxes are $212,887.68; and the disbursements for the same period $551,231.10. This estimate does not include any expenditures for objects not now authorized by the Council, or which are not regular annual expenditures.
The Finance Committee say that the Council will have to provide for at least $30,000, besides the difference in the Auditor's estimate, to meet unestimable expenditures, which, under a system of the most rigid economy, will require an increase of the taxes to fully thirty-five per cent. A sale of the city bonds, under existing circumstances, could only be made at a sacrifice; and the committee declare their opinion that however disagreeable it may be to increase the taxes at this time, it is the only alternative left, and the farthest they can go is to recommend that $50,000 be raised when it shall be needed, by a sale of the bonds or other property, or by a temporary loan; and that the balance shall be provided for by an increase of the taxes.
The ordinance submitted by Mr. Grattan provides that the tax on real estate shall be 110 per cent., on personal property 100 per cent., and on money and credits 65 per cent.
The estimates of the City Engineer and the Superintendent of Streets were also presented.

Mr. Denton, from the Committee on Schools, presented a report relative to the Schools in Monroe Ward.
A petition from Rev. John Woodcock, for pay for services rendered as teacher, was rejected by a tie vote, after a protracted debate.

Mr. Scott, from the Committee on the Fire Department, reported adversely on a petition relative to locating the hose in various parts of the city; also, from the same committee, an ordinance to amend the ordinance regulating the Fire Department, making the pay of the engineer of the steam engine $600, and of the fireman and hostler $400 each — payable monthly.
(This proposes a small increase of pay to the fireman and hostler, but the pay of the engineer is the same.)
The report was agreed to.

Mr. Hill presented a petition from B. Hassel, praying that any official publications made by authority of the Common Council in the English language, may be likewise printed in German in the Anzieger. Referred to the Committee of Finance.
A resolution, offered by Mr. Scott, for grading M street, between 9th and 10th, (French Garden Hill,) was referred to the Street Commissioners.

Mr. Burr presented a communication from the City Engineer, advising repairs to the powder magazine, and offered a resolution appropriating $75 for that object.
Adopted,
Mr. Denton offered the following, which was adopted:

Resolved, That the balance left of the appropriation made for making and putting down the 24-inch main of pipes for the City Water Works, be appropriated, with the sum of $4,000 more, to pay for the 16-inch main of pipe, which is being manufactured by a contract made between Joseph R. Anderson & Co and the city of Richmond.
The Council then adjourned.

div3.head: Suspicious characters arrested — some Developments.
div3.p:
--On Sunday night Capt. Wilkinson received information, at the watch-house, of the whereabouts of a party of youths who had given the police some trouble, and, with watchmen Gilman and Pleasants, went to Stewart's cook-shop and arrested Fountain Rowe, John D. Anaker, and Wm. H. Gallaher, who were arraigned before the Mayor yesterday as persons of evil name and fame.
The officers above mentioned, together with Messrs. Perrin and Baptist, were called on to testify as to the moral status of the young gentlemen, and painted their characters black enough in all conscience.

Messrs. Darracott and Harris, clothing merchants, deposed to the fact that their store was robbed a few weeks ago, and that the prisoners had on certain articles of apparel that came from their establishment.

Mr. Low, a grocer, who lives next door to J. B. Foster's store on Cary street, gave a narration of a burglary at Mr. Foster's on Tuesday morning of last week.
He was aroused by his " old woman" about 3 o'clock, and hearing strange noises, got up, lighted a lamp, armed himself with a sword, and went forth to explore the premises.
He discovered three burglars in the act of getting in, attacked them bravely with his sword, called lustily for the watch, and they retreated without loss of time.
He could not swear that the prisoners were the same persons, although they resembled them.
Watchman Baptist deposed to having seen some of the party the same morning, about 2 o'clock, on the Basin bank.
They went to 10th street and down Cary, soon after which he heard the cry of watch.
When he got to Foster's the party was gone.
A witness named Austin Connelly, was introduced by Rowe, to prove that he purchased the clothes he wore from some unknown person, in Connelly's house.

After a patient investigation, the three were committed to jail, in default of $200 security each, for their good behavior.
Mr. Gilmer appeared as counsel for Anaker, Mr. Lewis Randolph for Rowe, and Mr. Caskie for Gallaher.

div3.head: Hustings Court.
div3.p: --The monthly term of the Court of Hustings commenced yesterday--Aldermen Sanxay, Bray, Timberlake, Anderson, Regnault, and Binford, presiding.
Wm. T. Moore, charged with feloniously shooting a negro named John, on the night of the 6th instant, was examined and discharged from further prosecution:
Harvey Walsh, charged with having in his possession and passing counterfeit gold coin, was, after a hearing, remanded for final trial.

Thomas Gwynn, a free negro, charged with making a felonious assault upon the late Wm. Byrd Page, was arraigned and pleaded not guilty.
After hearing part of the evidence, the Court continued the case until to-day.
The Grand Jury presented the following:
Commonwealth vs. William Wasley, an indictment for a misdemeanor — a true bill.
Commonwealth vs. Granville Montelle, misdemeanor — a true bill.
Commonwealth vs. John Hughes, misdemeanor — a true bill.
Commonwealth vs. John Henry Lambert, misdemeanor — a true bill.
Commonwealth vs. Moses McDevitt, misdemeanor — a true bill.
Commonwealth vs. Joseph Parrish, misdemeanor — a true bill.
Commonwealth vs. Thomas J. Pitts, misdemeanor — a true bill.
Commonwealth vs. Wm. Cavenagh, Thos. Devlin and James McCorson, misdemeanors — a true bill.
The Grand Jury also made a presentment against Wm. Kingstry, for an assault; and were then adjourned over to Wednesday at 12 o'clock.
In the case of William Wasley, the matter having been settled between the defendant and prosecutor, a nolle prosequi was entered and the defendant discharged on payment of costs.

div3.head: A Swarm.
div3.p:
--A large number of negroes were before the Mayor yesterday, chiefly for congregating unlawfully in houses of evil repute, low gambling establishments, grog-shops, and such like.
After disposing of the several cases, the Mayor warned each and every one that if they, or any others of their class, were caught in such places again, they would be punished to the full extent of the law. One smart looking chap took the liberty of reminding his Honor that he drove his carriage when the Prince of Wales was here; but the only consolation this remark elicited was a hint that if he was hereafter found in a gambling house he would get several prints of wales on his unlucky shoulders.

A good many negroes congregated about the Court-room to witness the proceedings, and having been previously admonished in vain, the Mayor gave an expressive order to the officers, who succeeded in capturing eight of them.
They were at once conducted to the basement, where they received an admonition of another sort.

div3.head: The Poor.
div3.p:
--In a brief suggestion yesterday in regard to the poor of the city, we unintentionally did injustice to the gentlemen who have been engaged in the work of benevolence during the present season.
It is utterly impossible for them to procure employment for the large number of persons to whom they have been furnishing the means of subsistence.
They have assisted 350 families, consisting of 1800 persons, and never bestow charity unworthily.
Before giving aid, the inquiry is always carefully made whether the object is really meritorious, and by this means they avoid imposition.

div3.head: Young Men's Christian Association--meeting to-night.--
div3.p:
By an advertisement in another column, it will be seen that this society, which seeks the mental and religious improvement of young men, holds its regular monthly meeting to-night.
An essay is announced from a young gentleman (as we learn) of talent.
A committee presents an interesting report, on which proceedings of importance to all the members will be had. In the present surfeit of "secession and coercion" conversations and speeches, it will be a relief to hear something in which the "crisis" is not the theme.
Let all the members and citizens generally foster and sustain this excellent institution, with its fine library and lectures, and other agencies.

div3.head: A Rogue.
div3.p:
--Joseph Grey, a free negro, was before the Mayor yesterday for unlawfully taking a horse and cart belonging to A. D Gatewood, which have been since restored to the owner.
Joe was sent to the post of punishment, and afterwards placed in the chain gang.
He had a bad reputation before, and seems to have no inclination to reform.

div3.head: Interments.
div3.p:
--During the quarter ending the 31st of December, 1860.
there were 198 interments in Shockoe Hill Burying Ground, viz: white males 51, white females 39, stillborn 7; colored males 59, females 33, stillborn 9.
In Oakwood Cemetery during the quarter there were 20 interments, viz: white males 4, females 6; colored males 6, females 4.

div3.head: Distressing Occurrence.
div3.p:
--On Saturday last, a distressing accident occurred at the residence of Mr. James C. Cowarding, on Brooke Avenue. His little daughter, Mary Ann, aged ten years, was terribly burned by the ignition of her clothing.
We heard yesterday that the chances of her recovery were very slight.

div3.head: Unlawful Assembly.
div3.p:
--On Sunday last, officers Seal, Chalkley, Morris and Davis made a descent upon John Noker's house, on 12th street, and found a large congregation of negroes playing cards and having a gay time generally.
The Mayor imposed a fine of $15 upon the proprietor.

div3.head: Theatre.
div3.p: --The interesting drama of "Rose Elmer" will be repeated to-night, to be followed by the farce of "Disunion and Compromise." To-morrow night the play of the "arlor and Cabin" will be performed for the benefit of the gentleman who dramatized the story.

div3.head: The Prize Saddles.
div3.p: --We are requested to state that one of the saddles contested for by the Governor's Mounted Guard, last Saturday, was presented by Mr. Cottrell, and the other by Mr. Gerhardt Kann.

div3.head: Sale of a Steam-Tug.
div3.p: --It is currently reported that the iron steaming James Gray, belonging to the Towing Company of this city, has been sold to the Government of South Carolina for $30,000.

div3.head: Fatal accident.
div3.p: --A laborer named Thomas Devlin, while at work on the York River Railroad, near this city, last Sunday morning, was run over and so badly injured that death ensued.

div3.head: Fined.
div3.p: --Ann James was fined five dollars by the Mayor yesterday, for permitting negroes to assemble unlawfully on her premises on 17th street.

div3.head: Continued.
div3.p: --The case of Orris Harrison, charged with stabbing Miles McJordon, was further continued yesterday, in consequence of the absence of witnesses.

div3.head: The Convention.
div3.p: --Many members of the State Convention have arrived, and the remainder will probably be here in time to take their seats to-morrow.

div3.head: Regimental Orders.
div3.p: --The orders promulgated by Col. Moore, this morning, will interest the several companies of the First Regiment.

Continues to Rent out Houses, Hire out Negroes, sell Real Estate, sell Negroes, and act as a General Agent.

div3.head:
Lawrence S. Marye,
Attorney at Law,
div3.p: Practices in the Courts of the city of Richmond and the counties of Henrico, Hanover and Carolina.
He is also Notary public and Commissioner of the United States Courts of Claims.
The partnership between Mr. Chastain White and himself being dissolved, his office is now on 11th st., just below Goddin's Hall.
--Corner of Franklin and 5TH streets.--The second half of the session of this School, for 1860-'61, will commence on the 15th of February and end the 30th of June next ensuing.

The Rev. Francis J. Boggs has been added to the Board of Instruction, and will, with his family, reside in the Institute buildings.
The Musical Department will continue under Mr. Chase's superintendence, who will be aided by competent assistants.
A gentleman has been employed to take charge of the classes in Algebra, and others will be to teach other specific studies; and another female teacher will be employed.
The Lectures on Biblical Literature, by Rev. Jas. A. Duncan, will be continued, as also the Friday Afternoon Literary Lectures.
The Preparatory Department, for very small girls, will receive the special care of the Principal of the School.
The Boarding Department will be liberally and carefully conducted, and every comfort and facility will be afforded to young ladies boarding in the family.
No labor or expense will be spared to make the School equal to any in the land for the education of females.
For further information, address
J. E. Shumate, Principal.
Richmond, January, 1861.

div3.head: Home-manufactured Iron.
div3.p: --A large assortment, consisting of Bar, Band, Hoop, Scroll, Ovals and Half-Rounds; Horse and Mule Shoe, Coach and Buggy; Steel and Iron Tyres, Rounds, Squares, &c., for sale at the Richmond Iron and Steel Works, foot of 9th street. Jas. Hunter.
Also — A large assortment of "Punched Washers," made at this establishment, to which the attention of dealers, car-builders &c., is called.

div3.head: The Virginia Convention.
div3.p:
This most important body which has assembled in Virginia since the Revolutionary era, will meet to-morrow at 12 o'clock, in Mechanics Hall, which has been fitted up in an admirable manner for its accommodation.
Its members are rapidly arriving.
We observed in the arrivals yesterday, some of the most distinguished amongst them.
It will be a body of very considerable dignity and ability --equal, it is to be hoped, to the moment tons occasion which calls its members together.
The Dispatch Will contain daily sketches, representing faithfully the general tenor and spirit of its proceedings.

div3.head: James River and Kanawha Canal.
div3.p:
In the pressure of other subjects demanding more immediate attention, we have unduly neglected the proceedings of the James River and Kanawha Company, at their last meeting.
We will, therefore, briefly state, that the President of the company, Colonel Ellis, made a most satisfactory statement of affairs, in connection with the executory agreement entered into with the Brothers De Bellot des Minieres. He submitted all the letters received from M. Ernest de Bellot since his arrival in France.
They were of a most satisfactory character.
and clearly established the disposition, as well as ability of the parties concerned, to do everything they had promised.
The requisite amount of capital has already been secured in France, in a manner which M. de B. esteems perfectly satisfactory.
The parties have been engaged in discussing matters affecting their own organization.
They avow a perfect readiness to comply with the contract, as it now exists, in all its particulars, as soon as it shall have been ratified by the Legislature.
At the same time, they express a hope that that body will modify it in some particulars, which they think bear hard upon them.--Everything being ready, they are only delayed from proceeding farther by the startling events that have been following each other with such rapidity in this country.
They profess, in the strongest terms, their ability to do everything they have undertaken to do, provided they be not interrupted by a general civil war. In the meantime, the Secretary of the Commonwealth has prepared a charter, in which all the laws upon the subject have been carefully considered, and modified to suit existing circumstances.
Such provisions as are deemed necessary in view of the foreign influence brought to bear upon the question, have been made, and the whole is under consideration by the proper committee of the Legislature, by whom it has been ordered to be printed.
President Ellis also laid before the Board a report by M. Alfred Paul, the French Consul, to his Government.

This report does great credit to the ability and industry of Mr. Paul. He appears to have made himself acquainted with all the details connected with the history of the canal, numerous and tedious as they necessarily are, and has given the results of his investigations with great accuracy and clearness.
Very many of our own people, we suspect, might learn from Mr. Paul what they do not know, although they have been living all their lives in sight of the canal.
Judging from his report, we should say he knew much more about it, even, than some of the Directors.
Of course Mr. Paul sees at once the immense importance of the work to the commerce of Virginia, of the West, of France, and of the world.
Any stranger can see it at a glance.
It is so palpable that nobody could miss it, except people born on the spot.
They are slow to see it. but even they begin to open their eyes.
We recommend Mr. Paul's report to all persons who wish to learn, in the shortest space of time possible, the most of their own great State improvement.

Mr. Paul reiterates an opinion formerly expressed by him, in a communication to which he alludes, that until Virginia shall have completed her lines of communication with the great West, projects for direct trade will be premature and ill-considered.
This great object having been once accomplished, however, by the completion of the James River and Kanawha improvement on an expanded scale, Virginia must at once become the commercial point of most interest to France — he might have said to Europe.
The arguments by which he supports this proposition are incontrovertible, springing, as they do, out of undeniable facts and the inevitable laws of trade.
Of the three routes by water now in existence, for the trade of the West--that of New York by the Erie Canal, that of New Orleans by the Mississippi, and that of Canada by the Lake and the St. Lawrence, the shortest is farther by several hundred miles from the grand centre — Cincinnati — than the James River and Kanawha route will be. For example, the distance from New York by way of the Miami Canal, Lake Erie, the Erie Canal and the Hudson, is 1,083 miles. The distance from New Orleans by way of the Ohio and Mississippi, is 1,724 miles, The distance to the mouth of the St. Lawrence, (Montreal, Canada, route,) by way of the Miami Canal, Lakes Erie and Ontario, the Welland Canal and the St. Lawrence River, is 1,660 miles.--The distance from Norfolk by the river, the canal and the Ohio, is 792 miles. Norfolk is two hundred and ninety miles nearer than N. York, nearly a thousand nearer than New Orleans, and nearly nine hundred nearer than the mouth of the St. Lawrence.
It should not be forgotten, too, that while the navigation of the Mississippi is one of the most dangerous in the world, and while the navigation of the lakes is also beset with innumerable difficulties, the route from Norfolk to Cincinnati is almost entirely divested of risks.
Who ever was cast a way on the "raging canal?" If you shorten the trip by stopping here, there is no conceivable risk whatever, except the very slight one between the Kanawha and Cincinnati.
Safety and shortness of distance are elements in commercial travelling sufficient of themselves to determine a choice of routes in almost any conceivable case.

But these are very far from being all. The route to the Kanawha will be open for at least eleven months, on an average, in every year.
Five months are the shortest period which the Erie or Welland Canal ever is frozen in a year.
The lower Mississippi is deserted almost entirely during the summer and fall months.
Little business is transacted in New Orleans from August to November.--The business season here lasts from the first day of January to the last day of December.
All the year, except Christmas week, is business time with us.

We hope the Legislature will put the finishing stroke to this important business, which we feel assured is declined to have a most beneficial and a most permanent influence upon the destinies of Virginia.
We shall recur to the subject.

div3.head: Gov. Wise--the Raid on Washington.
div3.p:
The letter of Gov. Wise drives the last nail in the coffin of this gigantic humbug.
Yet it is on the transparent pretext of a conspiracy for seizing Washington, of which Wise is the alleged head, that Gen. Scott is concentrating the U. S. Army in the Federal capital, at the instigation, we have no doubt, of Seward; thereby forming a nucleus for an immense force, if such should become necessary, to overrun and coerce the South.

div3.head: New publications.
div3.p:
Elements of Military Art and Science; or, course of instruction in Strategy, Fortification, Tactics of Battles, &c., embracing the duties of Staff, Infantry, Cavalry, Artillery, and Engineers.
Adapted to the use of Volunteers and Militia.
Second edition, with critical notes on the Mexican and Crimean Wars.
By H. Wager Halleck, A. M., late Captain of Engineers, United States Army.

div3.head: Correction.
div3.p: --In Art. 1, see. 7, of the Constitution of the Southern Confederacy, published by telegraph yesterday, it should have read as follows: "The importation of African negroes, from any foreign country other than the slaveholding States of the United States, is hereby forbidden, and Congress is empowered to pass such laws as shall effectually prevent the same,"

div3.head: The Legislature.
div3.p:
A bill was reported in the Senate yesterday to authorize the Governor to commission " Home Guards"independent of military organizations.
Resolutions were offered for authorizing the standing committees to report all bills of last session not acted on by the House of Delegates, and for incorporating the Southern Institution for the amelioration of the condition of deaf, dumb and blind negroes.
A number of acts of incorporation were passed.

In the House, bills were reported for increasing the salary of the Clerk of the Penitentiary, and for paying the recently appointed Commissioners for their services to the State.
Resolutions were offered for authority to free negroes to enslave themselves, and for allowing the Wise Light Dragoons to arm with a less number than now required by law. Sundry local bills were passed.
A petition was presented from Gloucester, asking the repeal of certain restrictions on the catching of oysters.
A report of Hon. John Robertson. Virginia Commissioner to certain seceding States, was returned by the Governor to the House, read and ordered to be printed.

div3.head: The Southern Confederacy.
div3.p:
The "Southern Confederacy," now a fixed fact, has been already announced in our columns.
The telegraphic sensation dispatches, which have been flooding the country for several days, with reference to the proclamation of free trade with all the world, and other reports intended to irritate the border States, have all been exploded by the authentic intelligence of the proceedings of the Convention.
We have already said that we never heard as many falsehoods circulated in thirty years, as there have been within the last three months about the action of the Gulf States.
The sixteen dollar tax on negroes in South Carolina, the forced loans, the misery and starvation in Charles ton, the conspiracy to revive the slave trade, and lastly this balderdash about free trade, are but a few out of a thousand slanders, manufactured out of the whole cloth for political purposes.
It seems as if the Father of Lies had taken the field in person, as Field Marshal of the crusade against the Southern States.
The very first action of the Southern Confederacy spikes the principal guns aimed at the new Republic.-- The slave trade is the first thing prohibited.--The Committee on Finance has been instructed to report promptly a tariff for raising revenue for the support of the Government. --This committee will undoubtedly report a measure of moderate duties for revenue, levied on imports, and then the delightful bugbear, raised by those inventive geniuses who have been trying to scare the South into the idea of two separate sets of tax collectors, both levying directly from the pockets of the people, for the support of the Government, will be entirely dissipated.
We have been especially gratified with the manly and noble action of the Convention, as embodied in Art. 6, clause 2 of the Constitution; "The Government hereby instituted shall take immediate steps for the settlement of all the matters between the State forming, and their other late confederates of the United States, in relation to the public property and public debts at the time of their withdrawal from them, these States hereby declaring it to be their will and earnest desire to adjust everything pertaining to the common property, common liabilities, and common obligations of that Union upon principles of right, justice, equity and good faith." Let the General Government meet this just and honorable proposition in the same spirit, and an equitable adjustment can be peaceably made, and the horrid alternative of civil war be avoided.

The gentlemen chosen to preside over the new Government will command for it universal respect and confidence.
Gen. Jeff. Davis, in iron will and military genius, is nearer Andrew Jackson than any other man on the stage of public affairs, whilst in sagacious statesmanship and culture of mind he is probably superior to that most popular of modern Presidents. A. H. Stephens, the Vice President, is one of the most eminent and incorruptible of the public men of the present day. His name will be a tower of strength to the new Republic.
This Confederacy, composed of six States, the chief cotton-producing States of the world, to which Texas and Arkansas will soon be added, will, in conformity with precedent and from the necessity of the case, be at once recognized by England, France, and the other European Powers.
We shall then begin to realize the deplorable loss which the Union has sustained in a magnificent Republic, containing the most valuable elements of commerce which this country possesses, and enjoying the most unparalleled advantages of climate, soil, and production of any spot of equal extent on the whole surface of the earth, gone, gone by the selfish ambition of such political knaves as Seward, and the Puritan fanaticism which he has used as the convenient engine of undermining the rights of the South, and which has compelled the Gulf States at last to believe — honestly, we doubt not — that until the politicians, demagogues and fanatics are all dead, buried, and damned, and until the principles of selfish ambition and of fanaticism are eradicated from human nature, there can be no safety for the Gulf States, where slavery is a vital necessity, except in separation and independence.
It requires more philosophy than we can command to contemplate with composure the folly and the wickedness of those pestilent abolition politicians and fanatics who have at last succeeded in casting "a pearl away richer than all their tribe."

div3.head: Georgia and the guns.
div3.p:
There is a broad grin over everybody's face at the lightning-like rapidity with which the New York police let go the guns, as soon as Georgia seized the New York vessels! It was one of the most beautiful electrical exhibitions we have ever witnessed.
The Governor of Georgia standing at the Savannah end of the telegraph wire, gives the New York Dogberrys, standing at the New York terminus, a single shock, and, presto!
the muskets drop out of their fingers as if their hands had been paralyzed by the lightnings of Heaven.
We don't believe that, since guns were invented, muskets ever went off before as quickly as these Georgia guns.
If the New York police always discharge their weapons as rapidly as they have just done when the Governor of Georgia drew their fingers on the trigger, they would be invaluable in a battle.

We trust the Southern public will not fail to observe all the points, instructive, suggestive and admonitory, which are contained in this single transaction.
First, is the confessedly illegal robbery of the guns, on a par entirely with the robbery of Southern property which has been going on from the beginning; secondly, the contemptuous refusal of the wrong-doers to make amends; thirdly, the inability of everybody, whether implicated in the transaction or condemning it, to have justice done; and fourthly, the instant surrender of the guns when the money nerve was touched.
When G. B. Lamar, Esq., President of the Bank of the Republic in New York, at the instance of the Governor of Georgia, made a formal demand upon Superintendent Kennedy, of the New York Police, for the Georgia arms which they had illegally seized, the Superintendent refused to give them up, and the Republican journals, with their usual good manners, spoke of the agent of Georgia as "one Lamar." When the Governor of Georgia made the same demand upon the Governor of New York, the latter replied that he could not, under his oath to the General Government, so far as he had any control, permit arms to leave the State which might be turned against its own citizens, thus showing that the police were acting under his orders, and that he did not intend the arms should be restored.
But the very moment the ships were seized by Georgia, the "oath" of the New York Governor no longer stood in is way, and the Georgia property was restored, not because that restoration was just and right, but because N. York property was made responsible for its restoration.
When we see a Governor of New York authorizing downright robbery under the pretext of his "oath" and conscience, and then giving up his "oath" and the stolen goods together, at the first act of retaliation, is it not evident that the South can place no reliance on the principles, or even the "oaths" of her enemies, but simply and alone upon their interests?

div3.head: Senate.
div3.p: Called to order at 12 o'clock--Lieut. Gov. Montagu in the chair.
Prayer by Rev. Mr. Woodbridge, of the Monumental Church.

Bills Reported.--By Mr. Carraway, a bill authorizing the Governor to commission and arm Home Guards, independent of military organizations; a bill establishing a branch Bank in the town of Jeffersonville.

Resolutions.--The following resolutions were adopted: By Mr. Neeson, that the standing committees be authorized to report all bills of last session which were not acted on by the House of Delegates; by Mr. Finney, of authorizing Wesley James, an idiot, to be received into the Lunatic Asylum at Williamsburg; by Mr. Johnson, of incorporating the Southern Institution for the amelioration of the condition of deaf, dumb and blind negroes; (bill reported;) by Mr. Neeson, of incorporating the Industrial Society of Wood county.

Bills Passed.--The following Senate bills were passed: A bill establishing a branch Bank at the town of Liberty, in the county of Bedford; a bill to amend and re-enact an act incorporating a company to construct, on the plan of James S. French, a railroad between Alexandria and Washington; a bill to incorporate the Lynchburg Arms and Engine Manufacturing Company; a bill to amend the charter of the Merchants' Bank of Virginia; a bill to authorize the Merchants' Bank of Virginia to establish branches at Rocky Mount, Liberty, Goodson and Princeton; a bill to incorporate the Manchester Savings Bank; a bill to incorporate the Hebrew Benevolent Society of Alexandria; a bill to incorporate the Independence Male and Female College in the county of Grayson; a bill to incorporate the Amherst and Nelson Woolen Manufacturing Company, in the county of Nelson; a bill to incorporate the Southern Manufacturing Company, (to be located either in Richmond city, town of Manchester, or county of Henrico;) a bill to incorporate the Springfield and Deep Run Coal Mining and Manufacturing Company, in Henrico county; House bill incorporating the Berkeley Springs Savings Bank in the town of Bath in the county of Morgan; House bill entitled an act to amend the charter of the Bank of Howardsville; a bill to incorporate the town of Cannon in the county of Marshall.
On motion of Mr. Taliaferro, the Senate adjourned.

div3.head: House of Delegates.
div3.p: The House was called to order at 12 o'clock M. by Speaker Critchfield, and opened with prayer.

Bills Reported.--Mr. Haymond, from the Finance Committee, reported a bill increasing the salary of the Clerk of the Penitentiary, which was read a first time and ordered to a second reading.
He also reported a bill for paying commissioners which likewise read the first time.

Resolutions.--The following resolutions of inquiry into expediency were offered: By Mr. McKinney, of reporting a bill for the voluntary enslavement of certain free persons of color emancipated by the last will of A. J. Gordon, dec'd; by Mr. Martin, of Norfolk county, of authorizing the Wise Light Dragoons, of Norfolk county, to arm with a less number than fifty regularly uniformed members; by Mr. Boreman, of incorporating the Industrial Society of Wood county.

Bills Passed.--The following bills were read the requisite number of times and passed, viz: A bill increasing the capital stock of the Elk River Turnpike Company; amending the charter of the Bank of Scottsville; amending certain acts concerning the town of Port Royal, in Caroline county; Incorporating the Gilmer Mining and Manufacturing Company in the county of Gilmer; incorporating the Elk River Railroad Company.

Memorial.--Mr. Jones, of Gloucester, presented a memorial of citizens of his county, asking the repeal of such laws as prohibit the catching of oysters in certain months, which was referred to the Committee on Propositions and Grievances.

Report of Commissioner to Seceding States.--The Speaker laid before the House a communication from the Governor, enclosing a report from Hon. John Robertson, Virginia Commissioner to South Carolina and other seceding States, which reads as follows:

opener.salute: To His Excellency the Governor of Virginia:

div4.p:
--Very shortly after my brief dispatch to you of the 29th inst., from Charleston, I received a letter from Ex-President Tyler, in which he informed me that the President would send the resolutions to Congress with a recommendation to abstain from all hostile measures.
He (Mr. Tyler) regarded this as virtually an assurance of pacific intentions on the part of the President.
He informed me, moreover, that the late Senators and Representatives of Alabama had written to the Governor of that State advising him to withdraw the State troops altogether.

These facts seemed to justify some hope of still accomplishing the object of my mission.
I concluded, therefore, to proceed at least as far as Georgia and Alabama.

On my arrival at Milledgeville, I addressed a letter to Gov. Brown, accompanied by a copy of the resolutions of the General Assembly, and received a prompt reply inviting me to a personal interview the next morning.
At that interview we entered very fully into the subject of the Virginia resolutions.
He informed me that they had not been received by him until the day after the adjournment of the Georgia Convention.
That body, lie said, had full authority to act upon the proposition to appoint Commissioners to Washington, and added, that all he could now do would be to await its reassemblage, and, it not too late to be of any avail, lay the resolutions before it. I subsequently received his reply in writing in relation to the special object of my mission.

It affords me great pleasure to inform you that he accepts the mediation of Virginia, and gives the assurance that the authorities of Georgia will abstain, during the period contemplated, from all acts calculated to produce a collision of arms between that State and the Government of the United States.

Since my arrival here, I have, by the invitation of Governor Brown, had a frank and full conversation with him on the subject of the resolutions of the Virginia Assembly.
He informed me that they had been received very recently, and would be laid before the Legislature of Alabama tomorrow.
He leaves me no room to doubt that he also will give a favorable answer to the friendly mediation of Virginia in reference to acts of a hostile character or tendency.
To-morrow being the day fixed for the meeting of the Commissioners at Washington, it seems altogether unnecessary that I should visit the other seceded States.

I have some hope, however, of accomplishing the same object, by written communication to the Governors of those States, or through the influence or agency of their representatives in the Southern Convention, which commences its session here to-morrow.
I will only add, that I have good reason to believe that South Carolina will conform her course, in regard to hostile measures, to the action or recommendation of that Convention.
The correspondence between the authorities of the seceded States and myself will be submitted to you on my arrival in Richmond.
div4.closer:
Very respectfully,
John Robertson.
On motion of Mr. Collier, the communication was laid on the table and ordered to be printed.
Adjourned.

div3.head: Special notice.
div3.p: Owing to the inclement weather during the greater part of the time that we have held our sales in Richmond, many Ladies and gentlemen have been Unable to Visit our Store; and in consequence of this fact, and urgent requests from many of our patrons, we have made preparations to remain three days Longer — until Wednesday Evening Next.

As this is positively the last Chance, we are convinced that all in want of Rich and Valuable Jewelry, Will embrace this opportunity to procure articles for one Dollar that have been sold for ten Dollars and even thirty Dollars.
One Dollar for your Chance, from
our entire stock.
Remember, this is most Positively the last Chance, as our Stock will be removed to Lynchburg on Thursday Next.
All persons having bills against H. E. Hoyt & Co., are requested to present them upon the 13th. H. E. Hoyt & Co., 239 Main street,
Under Spots wood Hotel.

div3.head: Sergeant-at-arms.
div3.p: --We are authorized to announce Col. John H. Fuqua, of Amherst, as a candidate for the office of Sergeant-at-arms of the Virginia State Convention.

div3.head: Candidate for Constable.
div3.p: Wm. W. Stansfield is the People's Candidate for the office of Constable in the first district in Chesterfield county.

div3.head: The Convention.
div3.p: I hereby offer myself a candidate for Sergeant-at-arms of the Convention, and respectfully solicit the votes of the members.

div4.p: On the 11th instant, after a severe illness of three weeks. John Lafayette Wade, son of Edward A. and Virginia Ann Wade, aged 3 months and 17 days.

lg.l: Johnny came awhile on earth to smile,
Like early flowers in sunny bowers
But oh, no more his spirit pure
The little dove has flown above,
Though o'er his tomb in silent gloom
Johnny's blest and is at rest,

div4.p: His funeral will be preached at Oregon Methodist Chapel, this afternoon, at 4 o'clock. The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend.
On Sunday evening, the 10th inst., after a short illness, Mrs. Martha T. Jones, wife of Alfred O. Jones, and daughter of George K. Crutchfield, in her 25th year.
The friends and acquaintances of the families are requested to attend her funeral this morning, the 12th inst., at 11 o'clock, from the First Baptist Church.
In Manchester, Va., on the 11th inst., of brain fever, Annie Estelle, daughter of Armand V. and Emily J. Wagner, aged 22 months and 2 days.
Philadelphia Ledger please copy.
On Sunday night, after a protracted illness, Jno S. Vaughan, in the 43d year of his age.
The friends and acquaintances of the family are invited to attend his funeral, at 3 ½ o'clock, this day, from his residence, on 3d, between Clay and Leigh streets.

div3.head:
Office of the Richm'd & Danville R. R.
Co.,
div3.p: Tribute of Respect.--At a meeting of the Officers of this Company, hold this day, the following preamble and resolutions were adopted.

Whereas, it has pleased Almighty God to take from our midst our esteemed and beloved brother officer, John S. Vaughan, Treasurer of the Company, who, by his fidelity, kindness and courtesy to us, and all others, had endeared himself to us as a man eminently worthy of our respect and esteem; Therefore.
Resolved, That we tender to his bereaved family our heartfelt sympathy in their irreparable loss.
Resolved, That we attend his funeral in a body.
Resolved, That the Secretary furnish his widow with a copy of these proceedings.

Thos. W. Brocken Borough, Chairman.
Richard Hill, Secretary.
