div3.head: A Card.
div3.p: --Having been kindly informed, by some of our patrons, that a report was in circulation, that we sold liquor by the small quantity, to be drank in the store, said report may have been put in circulation by interested parties, in order to injure us; or, the impression may have been made, on the minds of some, from an advertisement which was put in the Dispatch. previous to the holidays, headed Egg-Nog, Hot Whiskey Punch, &c., which was only intended as a notice to the public that we had fine Irish Whiskey, Scotch Whiskey, and Jamaica Rum for sale, to those who wished to make the above drinks.

Be this as it may, we here say, that while we keep a choice stock of Brandies, Wines, Whiskeys, &c., &c., constantly on hand, we never have, or never intend to sell liquor of any kind to be drank in the store, while said business is under our control.
We have said this much as being due to ourselves, as well as to those who have so liberally patronized us.
div3.closer:
Minnis & Co., Choice Family Grocery,
2d and Main streets. fe 12--3t

div3.head: A Card.
div3.p:
--Richmond Theatre.--The great Southern Drama of "Parlor and Cabin;" or, "Masters and Slaves," will be repeated on Wednesday Evening Next, the 13th inst. , for the Benefit of the Author, a native and citizen of Richmond.
It is hoped, therefore, that our citizens, and visitors to the city, will turn out, on masse, on Wednesday Evening, and give the author of this excellent Dramatic defence of the South the encouragement he Deserves, by filling the house to Overflowing.
Besides the "Drama," other Novelties will be presented the same evening, with Singing, Dancing, &c., making the bill the best one of the season.
Secure your Seats at once.

monthly meeting of the Young Men's Christian Association.--The regular monthly meeting of the Young Men's Christian Association will be held this (Tuesday) evening, in their Hall, in Goddin's building.
The Essay for this meeting will be read by John H. Beal, Esq.
The committee charged with the consideration of subjects of great importance to the Association, will report at this meeting.
All the members are especially solicited to be present punctually at 7 ½ o'clock. The citizens generally are also invited to attend.

By order of the President.
Ro. E. Richardson, Sec'y. fe 12--1t

important to Engineers and Surveyors.--The subscriber having recently, made valuable improvements on his Engineering and Surveying Compass, and also on his Calculating Protractor, offers them for sale as the cheapest and best instruments of the kind now in use. Some of the great advantages of this Compass over those now in use, are, that any survey may be accurately taken without the use of the chain.
Also, the height and distances of inaccessible objects.
can easily be obtained, without the long and tedious calculations required to be made when using other instruments.

I opened a night School, on Monday night, Feb. 11th, at Messrs. John & Geo. Gibson's office, corner of Cary and 6th streets, for the purpose of teaching in a condensed form Practical Engineering and Surveying.
I guarantee that any gentleman who will place himself under my instruction, and give it proper attention for ten or twelve days, will, after a little practice, be fully able to compete with the more experienced Engineers and Surveyors, who have studied under the old system.
I am now engaged in teaching a class at Richmond College, my school hours being from 3 to 5 P. M. The course consists of from twelve to fifteen Lectures, of 3 hours each.
Terms.--$20 for the course.
I beg leave to refer to the following gentlemen, from some of whom I have the highest written recommendations as to the superiority of my instrument over all others now used:

Prof. Bledsoe and Assistant Profs. of Mathematics at the University of Va.; Prof. Turner, Richmond College; Profs. Bacon and Latham, Warrenton College; Prof. Burnley, of Jeffersontown; Messrs. Gill and Bates, City Engineers, and others.

Note.--The instruments.
mentioned above are the same as those exhibited by me at the late Fair of the Mechanics' Institute, and for which I received a first class Diploma.
The second term of this School commences on the 15th of February, when a few more pupils can be received.
Parents who entrust their children to Mrs. Pellet's care, are assured that they will be Thoroughly Grounded in all the branches essential to a finished education.

div3.head: University and Law School.
div3.p: --Professor Holcombe having resigned the chair of Civil, Constitutional and International Law, Equity, and the Law Merchant, in the University of Virginia, the Board of Visitors, at their meeting on the 6th of March next, will take into consideration the acceptance of his resignation, and the appointment of a successor.
Applications for the appointment should be addressed to the subscriber, at Charlottesville, Va.

div3.head: Special notice.
div3.p:
--I have an Ointment which will cure the Piles.
I warrant it to relieve the most obstinate cases, no matter of how long standing.
If it fails to cure or relieve, the money will be refunded; and I ask no one to try it, without feeling satisfied that it is no humbug.
I also assure them it is harmless in its use, but powerful and soothing in its effect, acting directly upon the affected part.
It gives no pain or inconvenience, and can be used when other remedies cannot be applied.
These afflicted need not fear a trial, as it is a prescription of a celebrated physician.
For sale by W. Peterson & Co., John T. Gray, or at my store, corner Broad and 25th sts.

div3.head: $20 reward
div3.p:
--Lost — Somewhere between Fayetteville, N. C., and Ashland, Va. , on the 22nd of December, 1860, Nine Shares of stock of the Fayetteville and Weston Railroad Company.
The finder will receive the above reward by returning it to me, at Ashland, Va., or Mr. C. B. Mallett, at Fayetteville, N. C.

div3.head: Stolen
div3.p:
--$59 reward.--Stolen from a trunk that was checked at Weldon, on Wednesday night, 23d January, the following articles: One Diamond Ring, with five diamonds set in a row; one Coral Bracelet; one set (Breastpin and Ear-Rings,) Blood Stone, in Etruscan setting; one regard Ring, with ruby, emerald, garnet, amethyst, ruby and diamond, all set in a row; one Gold Bracelet, marked "Maria to Josie, June 25, 1857:" one Gold Bracelet, chased, composed of several parts, connected with hinges; and one Mexican Earring.
The above articles were stolen somewhere on the route, between Weldon and Washington.
A reward of Fifty Dollars will be paid on their recovery and delivery to
div3.closer:
Samuel Ruth, Sup't Trans.
Office Richard, Fred. & P. R. R. Co.,
Richmond, 6th Feb., 1861. fe 6--ts]

div3.head: Headq'rs 1st Reg't Va. Vols.,

list.item: I. The several Companies of this Command will assemble, at Military Hall, in Undress Uniform, with arms and accoutrements, for Battalion Drill, at 7 ½ o'clock on the respective nights hereinafter mentioned:

II. Friday night, 15th inst., Company A
Monday night, 18th inst., Companies B, C, and E.
Tuesday night, 19th inst., Comp's F and I.
Thursday night, 21st inst., Companies G and K.

III.
The following Officers are hereby detailed to act as instructors:
Lieut. Col. Fry. Friday and Thursday nights.
Major Peyton, Monday night.
Major Munford, Tuesday night.

IV.
Order of Battalion Drill:
No. 1.--Close column, by company, on 1st, 2d, 3d and 4th companies, right and left in front.
Hardee; paragraphs No. 117 to 148, inclusive.
No. 2.--To deploy column on 1st, 2d, 3d and 4th companies, right and left in front; paragraphs No. 510 to 531 inclusive.
No. 3.--Forward, into line; paragraphs 440 to 448, inclusive.
No. 4.--Into line, face to the rear; paragraphs 466 to 476, inclusive.
No. 5.--Change front, forward; paragraphs 743 to 753, inclusive.
No. 6.--Change front to rear; paragraphs 760 to 773, inclusive.
V. The attention of the Officers of the Regiment is called to the above orders.

VI.
The First Sergeants are required to report all Absentees to the Adjutant of the Regiment, within five days after the above drills.
VII. Company H and the Artillery are excused, for the present, from the above drills.

div3.closer:
By order of
P. T. Moore, Col. Commanding.
G. G. Otey, Adj't. fe 12--4t

div3.head:
Astrologist.
great excitement.
Madame Adolph.
tremendous success.
div3.p:
Her Parlors crowded by the elite of the city.
This young lady is certainly the
Greatest Wonder Living.
Do not fail to give her a call, as she will shortly return to "Europe."

Now is your chance to consult the only true Astrologist in this country.
Madame can be consulted on all affairs of life, embracing Love, Sonship, Marriage, Sickness, Intemperance, Situations, Law Suits, Business, Traveling, Absent Friends, Lost or Stolen Goods, &c. She has also a Secret to make you Beloved by your Heart's Idol.
Madame will bring together those long and unhappily separated.

div3.head:
From Charleston.
[Special correspondence of the Dispatch.]
div3.p:
In writing to you yesterday I but reflected, in my own, the feelings of many here.
To-day we have some little hope that matters will yet meet with a peaceful settlement, notwithstanding I saw several of the officers yesterday in the city, calling on friends and relatives and bidding adieu for a season, at least.

This day's papers, as you will see, publish a notice declaring Sullivan's Island under martial law. This has been done through prudential motives, and, as I think, a very wise decision on the part of the Governor; for it may save the life of some one who might be reckless enough to venture too far.

A boat from Fort Sumter, which approached Morris's Island a few nights ago, with muffed oars, supposed to be looking for the precise locality of a formidable masked battery there, was fired into by a sentry four times before they could make good their retreat, and it is supposed damage was done.
To-day, about noon, "Old Secession" spoke again, telling us that a Provisional Government had been formed, and that on Monday a Provisional President would be elected.

Hon. Jefferson Davis is the favorite here as far as I have heard an expression, and no doubt but what he will be the choice of the Convention, though Hon. Mr. Stephens is regarded by many as decidedly the man for the times and some suppose he will be elected, especially as Mr. Davis is needed in another high and important position, that of Commander-in-Chief of the army.

You have noticed, no doubt, the fact that Gen. Brown, of Georgia, has seized five vessels of and from New York, at Savannah, as a retaliatory measure for the arms seized by the New York authorities, a few weeks ago, belonging to citizens of Georgia.
This may be called what boys used to play at school, "Tit for tat — kill my dog, I kill your cat. "

I got a long and interesting letter from an intelligent gentleman, elected to your State Convention as a Union man — a gentleman of great firmness, and representing the Union section about Danville, in which he says:

q.p: "Virginia will not secede if she can get her rights in the Union; if she cannot do that, the will certainly go with the South."

div3.p:
It is generally believed that South Carolina will attack Sumter in order to precipitate the Border States to secede, too. Be assured that such a sentiment does not obtain here.
If it is attacked at all, it will be solely from the conviction that it is dishonorable and cowardly to let a flag fly and the guns frown upon us, menacingly and defiantly, belonging to a Government to which we owe no allegiance, and whose rule the people abjure, and it would make no earthly difference with Carolinian whether another State had seceded or not, they will not let that flag float over their territory, though resistance to it devastated the State, and it will be made manifest before very long.

So far as Virginia is concerned, no one here believes for one moment that she will pollute herself by remaining with a people who have in every possible way attempted to degrade her people, to say nothing of their stealing, plundering and murder.

Virginia is held up to the execration of the civilized world, as the "slave breeder, " where "human beings are raised for the shambles," and to be sold as "mules or hogs;" and even their ministers of the Gospel, whose characters and piety have never been tarnished, refused admittance into their pulpits.

I see from all the English journals, that they are becoming terribly alarmed about their supply of cotton.
Well they may, when we supply them with seventy-seven (77) per cent.
of all they consume, and upon which one-sixth of the whole of Europe depends for their daily bread.
Moreover, these English journals tell the Black Republicans very plainly that if they attempt to blockade our harbors, they will inaugurate a game "that it takes two to play at. " Virginius.

div3.head:
From Washington.
[Special correspondence of the Dispatch.]
div3.p:
From all appearances the Union is preserved — with the bottom out. Jefferson Davis is elected President, and Stephens Vice President, of the Southern Confederacy.
A letter received last night from a former member of Congress, now at Montgomery, states that a strong Provisional Government will at once be organized, an army will soon be in the field, and ample preparations made for defence.
There will be no reconstruction.
The writer was a strong Union man, and had long hoped for reconstruction, but says the idea is now abandoned.
If Virginia had been in the new Confederacy, Hunter would have been elected President unanimously.
There is now, he adds, a yearning desire to have the great weight of Virginia's influence and counsels in the new government; but since she has preferred to remain with the North, it is, perhaps, best for the Gulf States.
He speaks of the good feeling prevailing among the members of the Southern Congress, the social gaiety of Montgomery, and seems to think the season there is even more pleasant than in Washington.

While nothing is certainly known in regard to the operations of the Peace Congress, the general conviction is that they will settle down upon the Border States proposition — which, you will remember, imposes the Wilmot Proviso over all territory north of 36 deg. 2 mm., and leaves all south of that line to be slave or free according to the doctrines of Squatter Sovereignty.
We already have the Dred Scott decision over all the Territories, and the effect of the Border States proposition reduced to a plain statement, would be this: In return for the privilege of allowing Lincoln to form a Republican party in our midst, by means of federal patronage, we make ready to the hands of the Republicans another bleeding Kansas, out of which they may make party capital enough to continue their existence at the North.
It behooves the people of Virginia to examine this proposition carefully, to ascertain whether it can, by possibility, be made the basis of a final settlement.

Some believe that Fort Sumter will be attacked to-night — all things being now ready for that purpose.
Others say that a dispatch came last night from Gov. Pickens to a prominent member of the Peace Congress, stating that no assault would be made for some time to come — probably not until Lincoln's inauguration.
Seward, it is said, is averse to coercion.
But there is a general and deep-seated feeling at the North that the laws must be enforced and the forts re-captured.
Lincoln is also averse to violent measures, but he is so committed to the opposite policy that one of the most sagacious men in Virginia declares he sees no loop-hole for Lincoln to escape.
It must be confessed that the complications are most serious.
How and when this Government is going to recognize the Southern Confederacy, no one can tell.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
effect of the American news in Rio — the Markets — the Don Pedro Railroad, &c.
div3.p: The intelligence brought by the steamer St. Louis, which arrived the 14th of this month, has caused a great depression in the coffee market, both on account of the money crisis and the Presidential election.
The buyers are holding back until the arrival of the English steamer, which arrives between the 1st and 4th inclusive, fearing the affairs in the United States may have affected the European markets.
From the 8th until the 22d, 70,300 bags were sold to the United States.
Round lots are quoted to-day as follows: U. 8, 5∥300a5∥500; English Channel, 5∥000a5∥200; North Europe, 5∥600a5∥800.
Different qualities as follows: Washed, 6∥200a5∥800; superior, 5∥700a5 ∥800; first good, 5∥300a5∥500; first ordinary, 5∥100a5∥200; second ordinary, 4∥700a5∥000.

The sales of flour have been, for the past week, as follows: From Octavia, 1,063 bbls. at 21¾500; Abigail, 200 bbls. Haxall at 23∥ 000; and 200 bbls. Columbia at 22∥000; Bansbee, 1,300 bbls. Baltimore Super.
at 14∥550; Esther, 500 bbls. Gallego at 23∥500; Conrad, 200 bbls. Philadelphia Family at 22∥000; Ida, 200 bbls. Irieste brand at 25∥000.
Remaining in first hands — Gallego, 1,000 barrels; Haxall, 6,610 barrels; other brands, 4,800 barrels. Total, 12,410 barrels.
Freights--Northern, 80 cents, per brig Amy Warwick, Southern nominal, although $1.20 has been given to New Orleans and $1 to New York.

The news from the Don Pedro II.
Railroad is very encouraging.
The "Tunnel Grande " is fast approaching completion, under the supervision of Jacob Humbird, of Maryland, assisted by Messrs. Ralston and Wood. Mr. R. was engaged as master machinist, but being a man of great energy, was placed in charge of an approach and one shaft, whose monthly estimates prove truly his value.
It is rumored that a change will take place in the Engineering Corps, at the head of which is Major Ellison, of Virginia, a very pleasant and affable person in his manners, always happy to see his fellow countrymen at his hospitable board.
Lady Franklin arrived by the St. Louis, and after visiting the Emperor, and other places of note, re-embarked and continued her journey the 17th of December.
The ferry boat Primeira, which sailed five days before the steamer, has not as yet made her appearance.
Dec. 25, 6 A. M.--Sold yesterday 16,000 bags of coffee, of which 15,000 bags were sold to the United States.
The bark Peter C. Warwick sails to-morrow for New York. H.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
election — accident, &c.

opener.dateline: New Plymouth, Lunenburg Co., Va.,, February 9, 1861.

div3.p:
The election passed off quietly, as Mr. Wm. Neblett, Secession candidate for this county, and no opposition.
A large majority voted against reference.

Mr. M. B. Hyden, formerly of Wytheville, Va., met with quite a serious accident a few days since.
While assisting to move some l at his saw-mill, he got his hand caught between two of them, which mashed it very badly.

The hard times seem to have cast a gloom over everything and everybody.
Howover, this little village seems to breast the storm bravely.
The merchants are doing a fine business for the times.
There is in process of erection here a fine mammoth hotel, owned and to be kept by Mr. Wm. T. Gary.

The military spirit runs high throughout this section of country.
Several new volunteer companies are being formed in this county.
Besides the names of many which have been added to the gallant corps, the Lunenburg Light Dragoons, commanded by Capt. James T. Staples.

The planters are very backward with their farming operations, owing to the wet weather.
Wheat looks badly.
The tobacco crop is being prized and sent to market much sooner than usual.
Richmond.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
things in Alexandria.
div3.p:
Our national difficulties have operated very seriously against the trade of this place.
I hear merchants complaining of the times as having paralyzed their business, though, thus far, there has been no failure of any importance.
Alexandria merchants, almost without an exception, weathered the great crisis of 1856, and they are hoping to pass through this.-- There seems to be a strong hope that a safe and honorable compromise will be made, by which the country will be saved.
Though the Union candidate (Mr. Brent,) received such an overwhelming majority for the Convention, there is here a strong Southern feeling, and a determination to have our rights in the Union or out of it.

The Marshall House has recently been opened, and has a very popular proprietor in the person of Mr. James W. Jackson, who guarantees "good fare, good beds, and pleasant rooms to all who honor him with their calls."

div3.head: Congressional.
div3.p: --Senate.--A bill was passed extending the right of appeal from the District Courts to the Supreme Court of the United States.
A resolution calling for the official correspondence with Great Britain in the case of the negro Anderson, charged with murder, and now in jail at Toronto, was laid over.
The President's Message was postponed until Thursday.
The Navy Appropriation bill was taken up. Among the amendments proposed, was one for the construction of seven new steam sloops-of-war.
Mr. Hunter opposed this amendment, on the ground that the vessels were intended for coercing the South, and that the Government was not in a condition to make the expenditure.
The amendment was agreed to — ayes 30, noes 18; but the Senate subsequently rejected it.
No action was had on the bill.

House.--Mr. Craige, of North Carolina, introduced a resolution requiring the President to acknowledge the Southern Confederacy, and receive their envoy or ambassador, and to adjust pecuniary matters with them.
Referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs.

Mr. Martin, of Va, introduced a resolution looking to a National Convention to adjust our present difficulties.
Referred to the Committee on Judiciary.
A resolution was adopted calling for information as to what measures have been adopted to recover the public property seized at New Orleans.
Another resolution was adopted, recommending the observance of the 22d February as a National holiday.

Mr. Palmer offered two resolutions.
The first was to the effect that neither the Federal Government nor the people of the free States have the right or purpose to legislate or interfere with slavery in any State.
Several members called for a division of the resolutions.

When the roll was being called on the vote, several Southern members declared it unfair that they should be called on to vote on the purposes of the North.
Quite an exciting time followed.

The resolution was adopted--114 to 4.
The vote was subsequently reconsidered, and Mr. Sherman offered the following as a substitute:
Resolved, That neither Congress, nor the people, nor Government of any free State, has the constitutional right to legislate to interfere with slavery in any slaveholding State.
This substitute was adopted unanimously by 161 votes.
Mr. Sickles offered a resolution calling for information relative to the seizure of the Mint at New Orleans.
Mr. Barnett offered an amendment, which was accepted, inquiring the reason of the concentration of Federal troops at Washington.
The resolution as amended was passed.

Mr. McKean endeavored to introduce a resolution looking to the emancipation, by purchase, of the slaves in the border States.
Laid over.
The Senate's Pacific Railway bill was made the special order for to-morrow.
Mr. Grow suggested an amendment, cutting Texas off from the benefits of the Southern route, in case she secedes.
The House agreed to the Senate's amendment to the Deficiency and Diplomatic Appropriation bill.
Adjourned.

div3.head: From Washington.
div3.p:
--Capt. Morrison, of the cutter Cass, has sent his resignation to the Treasury Department.
He acknowledges he surrendered his vessel to Alabama.
An order has been issued that resignations under such circumstances be accepted, but that the name of the officer be stricken from the rolls of the service.
Capt. Breshwood's resignation will be treated in the same way.

Some postmasters recently appointed in the seceding States, decline to take the oath of allegiance to the Union.
Such offices will be discontinued.
Congressman Rockwell, of Ct., died suddenly at his boarding-house, last night, of apoplexy.

div3.head: Marine Disasters.
div3.p:
--Schr. Empire, from Norfolk, for New York, was wrecked on Sand Shoals on the night of the 7th inst. The vessel and cargo of 13,000 bushels of corn, are a total loss.
Two of the crew were frozen to death.
Capt. Howell, and the rest of the crew, were badly frost bitten.
They were taken off at 3 p. m. next day, and are now at Cobb's Island.

Ship Utopian, of New York, 71 days from Callao, has arrived.
She lost overboard Jno. Kirk, of Dundee, Scotland.

div3.head: The Canada fugitive slave case.
div3.p:
--The case of Anderson, the fugitive slave, was argued at great length to-day by eminent counsel, and the case is still going on to-night.
There will be no decision given probably till next week, but the general impression is that the Court will liberate the prisoner on a technicality in the commitment.

div3.head: North Carolina Legislature.
div3.p: --The Legislature is busily engaged dispatching business.
Wake county has nominated Holden, editor of the Standard, Badger and Busbee for the State Convention.
The Legislature will probably adjourn next week.
The revenue bill is now under consideration.

div4.p: --The Union ticket has 400 majority here.
West Tennessee gives a Union majority.
--All the Union candidates are elected, as far as heard from.
In this city the Union ticket had 2,500 majority, and 1,000 majority was given against a Convention.

div3.head: Southern Congress.
div3.p: --Hon. A. H. Stephens, before the Congress, made a speech acknowledging the honor done him, in selecting him Vice President.
A bill was reported, providing for the Executive Department.

div3.head: Probable arrival of Tom Sayers.
div3.p:
--The name of "Sellers" appears in the Canada's passenger list.
It is misspelled, and is said to be Tom Sayers, the great English pugilist.

div3.head: Departure of Mr. Lincoln for Washington.
div3.p:
--Mr. Lincoln left at 8 o'clock this morning on his trip to Washington.
He made some brief farewell remarks, but with no political allusions.

div3.head: The Steamer General Miramon.
div3.p: --The steamer General Miramon sails for Havana on the 19th instant.

div3.p:
--Use the best Dentifrice, and pearly white teeth are insured.

Trustees' sale of very Valuable and desirable Private Dwelling, on Sixth, between Clay and Leigh sts. By virtue of a deed of trust, executed by Richard W. McGruder and wife to the subscribers, dated 14th February, 1860, duly recorded in Richmond Hustings Court, we shall proceed to sell, at pubblic auction, for cash, on the premises, on Thursday, the 21st February, 1861, at 4 o'clock P. M., (If fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter,) the very valuable Private Presidence located as above.
The lot fronts 50 feet on the east side of 6th streets, and runs back 130 feet. The improvements consist of a handsome Brick Dwelling (nearly new,) furnished in good style, with all modern conveniences, and amply sufficient for the accommodation of a large family.
The servants accommodations are good.
The location of this property is very desirable for a private residence.
The taxes for 1861 to be paid by the purchaser.

W. Goddin, Trustees.

div3.p:
Trustee's sale of very Valuable Farm of 700 acres, in New Kent county, on the York River Railroad, fifteen miles below Righmond.--By virtue of a deed of trust from R. L. Walker. Esq., dated 10 January, 1860, duly recorded in New Kent County Court on the 9th February, 1860, I shall, in execution thereof, proceed to sell at public auction, on the premises, on Friday, the 15th February, at 12 o'clock, (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter, except Sunday,) the very valuable Farm located as above, how in the occupancy of said Walker.
It contains, by recent survey, 700 acres, of which there is an ample supply of wood and timber (on the railroad,) for the use of the place.
The open land lies well, and it susceptible of great improvement.
A portion of it produces tobacco finely.
There is now seeded on the land 70 bushels of wheal, with five tons of guano.
The buildings on the place are comfortable, and are sufficent for the accommodation of a large family. "Dispatch " Depot, on the York River Railroad, is located on the land, and a post-office thereat, thus affording unusual facilities for the transmission of produce, intelligonce, and passengers to and from Richmond daily.

The deed required a cash sale; but by consent of parties the terms will be one-third cash; balance atone and two years, for bonds bearing interest, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes for 1861 to be paid by the purchaser.
As this is really a most desirable Farm, the particular attention of the public is respectfully called to this sale.

div3.head: By James M. Taylor & Son, Auct'rs.
div3.p: Ashland Hotel, and other Valuable Real and personal property, for sale-- By virtue or decree of the Circuit Court of the City of Richmond, entered the 23 day of January, 1861, in the suit of Todd o, al. vs. Robinson and al., the undersigned, Commissioner thereby appointed for the purpose, will sell at public auction, upon the premises, onWEDNESDAY, the 17th of April next, (if fair; if not, the next fair day,) beginning at 11 o'clock A. M., and contianing from day to day until the sale is completed, all the property, reall and personal, belonging to the Ashland Hotel and Mineral well Company in the bill in said cause mentioned, as follows:
Real Estate.

A Tract of land, containing about 40 acres, situated in the couty of Hanover, in the town of ashland, immediately upon the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad, about 16 miles from the city of Richmond, and known as the Ashland Hotel Tract, with all the improvements thereon, consisting of--

list.item:
1.
a large and handsome Hotel Building, erected withing the past few years, upon the most approved model, and capable, with the Cottages hercafter described, of accommodating 150 persons.
All the requisite out-buildings are attached to the Hotel, and among them a large Ball-Room, Bowling and Billard Saloons, all of which are fully supplied with gas and water.
The passengers by the great Northern and Southern Mail route now breakfast and sup at the Hotel.--Trains pass between Ashland and Richmond three times daily, and heads of families residing in Ashland, or boarding at the Hotel, will have the privilege of a free ticket on the cars to and from Richmond for the next 20 years, with the probability of its being extended indefinitely.
The Hotel has been for years past a popular resort of the citizens of Richmond, who prefer residing There with their families during the summer searson.

Detached from the Hotel, and placed at convenient distances from it, on the same 40 acre lot, are Nine Jiandsome Cottages, conveniently and testefully planned for the use of families boarding at the Hotel.
There are numerous shade and ornamental trees about the Hotel and Cottages, and the grounds are handsomely jaid off into grass plots, separated by gravelled walks, bordered by overgreens and flowers, whilst the buildings are so disposed, both with reference to conventience and beauty of arrangement, as to render the property not only among the most desirable for the purposes from which it was designed, but one of the most beautiful situations in the Southern country.
The parts of the lot not occupied by the buildings and ornamental grounds are in a high state of cultivation, and the whole is surrounded by a substantial and ornamental fence.
after the sale of the Real Estate, There will be sold at large quantity of personal property, consisting chiefly of--

1.
The entire stock of Furniture and Fixtures in the about the Hotel, Cottages, Ball Room, Billiard Sallon, Bowling Alley, Kitche, Laundry Bakery, Gas House, &c., comprising the usual variety used in such establishements, catalogues of which will be furnished on the day of sale.
2. The stock of provisions, of all kinds on hand at the hotel on the day of sale.
3. Thre or four Mules and a small lot of Farming Utensils, belonging to the said Hotel Company.

div3.p:
Terms Of Sale--Real Estate.--For so much of the purchase money not exceeding $20,000, one-fourth cash; or if the purchaser shall prefer it, for all of such payment as shall exceed the expenses of the sale, an approved negotiable note, well endorsed, interest added, at four months. The balance of the purchase money, not exceeding $20,000, in three equal instalments, at 6, 12 and 18 months, purchaser giving negotiable notes, well endorsed, with interest from the day of sale for the deferred payments.
For all the purchase money from the real estate exceeding $20,000, an arrangement can be made on the day of sale for extending the credit to suit the purchaser.
The possession of the property will be given immediately, but the title will be withheld until all the purchase money is paid.
Personal Property.--For all sums not exceeding $50, cash; for sums of $50 and upwards, and approved negotiable note, well endorsed, with interest added from the day of sale.

There is attached to the premises a Kitchen, Stable, and other out-buildings, together with a well of good water.
The lot fronts about 44 feet, and runs back 120 feet.
This property is particularly adapted for a grocery stand.

Terms of Sale.--One-fourth cash; the balance at 6, 12 and 8 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The taxes and insurance for 1861 to be paid by the purchaser.

div3.head: Commissioner's sale of House and Lot, on the North side of Grace St., as Extended into Henrico county.
div3.p:
--As Commissioner, appointed by a decree of the Circuit Court of Henrico county, pronounced on the 28th day of April, 1860, in the case of Perkins vs. Perkins' Executors, I shall proceed to sell, at public auction, upon the premises, on Thursday, the 14th day of February, (if fair; if not, the next fairy day thereafter,) commencing at 4½ o'clock P. M., the Real Estate in the bill mentioned, being the Brick Tenement, on the north side of Grace street, between Monroe and Henry streets, now occupied by Mr. W. S. Thaw.
The House is large and well arranged, and has every convenience for the accommodation of a large-sized family.

Terms.--One-fourth cash; the balance in three equal instalments on a credit of 6, 12 and 18 months; the eredit instalments to be secured by negotiable notes, with interest added, with an approved endorser, and the title to be retained till all the purchaser money is paid, and a conveyance directed by the Court. A. R. Courtney, Special Comm'r.
div3.closer: Sale conducted by James M. Taylor & Son, Auctioneers. fe 4.

div3.head: Extensive sale, by Auction, at Milford Depot, Caroline county, Va., commencing on Monday, 18th February, 1861.

div4.p: --On Monday, 18th of February, 1861, commencing at 10 o'clock A. M., we will offer our entire stock at auction, embracing House-hold and Kitchen Furniture, a large and good assortment; Farming Implements; Horse; Mules; Cows; Hogs; one good Family Carriage; Jersey Wagons; Farm Wagon; Cart, with Harness complete; stock of Fodder, Clover, Hay, Vegetables, &c., and about 1500 lbs. of good country-cured Bacon.

We also offer our Farm, with all the buildings thereon, for sale privately, until the day of auction; if not sold by that time, it will be offered at auction.
The Farm contains near about 160 acres, highly improved by the use of guano, lime, and other manures; adapted to the growth of corn, wheat, oats, and tobacco; under a new, good plank fence; (a crop of Boughton wheat now seeded;) a fine orchard of fruit trees, grape arbor &c. The Buildings are all in first-class order.
The Store and Hotel, now doing a fine business — and with the personal attention and energy of some one, could be made to do a tremendous business.--There is a Mill on the place, capable of grinding 200 bushels meal per day; Blacksmith's Shop and Plow Factory, now commanding a good rent, and doing a fine business.
Terms for Farming Implements, Household and Kitchen Furniture. --For sums of $10 and less, csh; all sums over that amount, 6 months, with approved security.
Terms for Real Estate.--One-fifth cash; balance on a credit of two and four years interest to be paid semi-annually, and a deed of trust to be given by the purchasers to secure payment of balances.
Possession can be had of the Farm immediately, and of the whole premises on the 1st March, 1861.
For further particulars, see hand-bills.
div4.closer:
Bragg & Ruth.
The sale to be continued from day to day until the whole is disposed of.

div3.head: Dissolution.
div3.p: --The partnership heretofore existing between Mason & Burns was dissolved on 7th January, 1861, by mutual consent.--The subscriber having become responsible for the liabilities of the late firm is only authorized to sign for said firm in winding up.
All partices having claims against Mason & Burns will present the same for liquidation, and parties indobted to M. & B. will please settle up as soon as practicable.

The subscriber grateful for past favors, takes the present opportunity to return ls most slucere thanks for the very liberal patronage be has received since going into the Soda Water Business, and begs leave to notify his customers and the public generally, that he will continue the Bottling Business, in all its branches, at the old stand, 21 Main street, where will be found the largest and best assorted stock of all articles in the Bottling Line, South and West of Baltimore.
div3.closer:

div4.p:
--The firm of Mason & Whiting was dissolved on the 4th February, by mutual consent.
The subscriber is alone authorized to settle all business of the late firm.
I shall continute the Painting business in all its branches, at the old stand of Mason & Whiting, Broad at., between 7th and 8th.
Thankful for past favors, I respectfully solicit a continuance.
Orders promptly attended to.
Work Faithfully Executed.
--The firm of Raymond & Byrne was dissolved on 7th January, 1861, by mutual consent.
The subscriber having assumed all responsibilities, is only authorized to sign for the late firm in settling up the business.

div4.head: Co-partnership notice.
div4.p:
--I have astociated with me in the Wholesale Liquor trade, Stephen Mason.
The business will be conducted under the style of Byrne & Mason, at the old stand, Cary street, three doors below 14th.
We have, and will continue to keep up, the largest and best assorted stock of Foreign and Domestic Liquors to be foundd in the city, which we offer to the trade at prices calculated to defy competition.

--The firm of Mason & Whiting expired on the 4th day of February, 1861, by mutual consent.
Mr. Mason is alone authorized to settle up the concern.
He (Mr. Mason,) is also responsible for all debts now owing from the concern.

div4.head: A Card.
div4.p:
--Having associated with me Mr. F. O. Mountcastle, we will continue to carry on the House and Sign Painting Business, in all its branches.
We hope, by strict attention, to give entire satisfaction to all who may favor us with their work.

Shop on Broad, between 5th and 6th streets, Richmond.
Va. Whiting & Mountcastle.
--I have this day associated with me in the Produce Commission Business, Dr. Peter H. Anderson, formerly of amella county, and late of Chesterfield, under the style and firm of Hicks & Anderson.

Messrs. Hicks & Anderson would respectfully tonder their thanks to the friends of the old concern for their patronage, and would solicit its continuance to the new firm.
With ample means we are prepared to make liberal strangements with the planters of Virginia and North Carolina.

The firm of Randolph & Page expired on the 31st January, 1861, by the withdrawal of D. C. Randolph, who has moved to the country.
They most cordially return their thanks for the liberal patronage bestowed on them by their very kind friends.
Either partner is authorized to close the business.
div4.closer:
D. Coupland Randolph,
Mann Page.
February 1, 1861.

div4.head: Notice.
div4.p:
--Intending to continue the Commission Business, I most respectfully ask a continuance of the patronage bestowed on the late firm of Randolph & Page, and hope, by strict attention, to merit the same.
My uncle, D. C. Randolph, who will probably be here often for the next few months, will aid me in my business.

--Having purchased of D. J. Saunders his interest in the stock, Fixtures, &c., of J. F. Saunders & Co., we will continue the business at the old stand lately occupied by them, under the firm and style of Saunders & Loving, where will always be found a well-selected stock of Grockeries, Liquors, &c., which will he sold at the lowest prices for cash, or to punctual customers on time, and to which we invite the attention of the patrons of the late concern of Saunders & Co., and the public generally — hoping, by strict attention to business, to give satisfaction to all who may favor us with a call.

In retiring from the firm of J. F. Saunders & Co., I return my thanks to my friends for the favors bestowed on me, and take great pleasure in recommending to then, and the public generally, my successors as gentlemen worthy of their patronage.
I would also request all persons having claims against the late concern of J. F. Saunders & Co., to present them for payment, and those, indebted will make payment to me, or to my son, J. F. Saunders, as early as possible.
div4.closer:
David J. Saunders.
Richmond, Jan. 21, 1861. ja 26--d15t&cw

div3.head: Exchange Hotel and Ballard House.
div3.p:
The proprietors of this well-known and popular establishment beg leave to return their heartfelt thanks to their friends and the public generally, for the liberal patronage they have at all times been favored with; an it affords them pleasure to announce that the recent changes, removals, and a thorough renovating of the entire establishment, makes it one of the most pleasant and comfortable Hotels (for permanent boarders, as well as transient company,) that can be enjoyed anywhere in the country.
It is due to the liberality of the Stockholders of the Exchange to say that everything has been done which could add to its value and increase the comfort and convenience of its guests.

Among the important changes and improvements in the Ballard House, they have added a well-arranged and convenient Restaurant, which is now open for the patronage of the public.
In arranging this part of their business, a handsome room has been provided for the ladies of the Hotel, with a private entrance from the parior floor of the Ballard House.
In view of the large expenditures, and renewed energy, and strict attention, on their part, they hope to merit a continuance of that patronage to long enjoyed by them.

div3.head: Commercial.
div3.p:
There is not the slightest change in our markets since last Friday, save a fraction advance in Bacon.
Commercial affairs remain in the condition of passiveness and incertitude which has characterized them for some months, and must so continue until some decisive measure for the pacification of the country shall be adopted.--Money matters unchanged.

div4.head: Tobacco.
div4.p:
--Sales still limited, at former quotations.
We notice the sales of some Lugs and common Leaf Lugs, $1.75@2.50; Leaf $3@4.50; some stemming Leaf $6@9.50; no fine manufacturing in market.
Stock on hand of the old crop very light, and mostly of inferior quality.

Flour.--There are no sales for shipment.
The stock of country is very limited, and sales confined to home consumption.
We quote $8.25@6.50 for Superfine; Extra $6.75@7; Family $7.50@7.75.
Wheat.--Receipts light and market firm at $1.50@$1.55 for White; $1.30@ $1.35 for Red.
Corn.--We still quote 60@65 cts. per bushel.
Oats.--30@35 cts. per bushel.

div4.head: Bacon.
div4.p:
--Demand moderate.
We quote Sides 11½ @11¼ cents; Shoulders 9½ cts.; plain Hams 12½ cents; Sugar-cured 13@13½ cents; Todd's Sugar-cured Hams 15 cents. Stock light.
Coffee.--We quote Rio 14@15 cents; Laguayra, 15½ @16 cts.; Java 1 8½ @19 cents; Mocha 18 cts.

Sugars.--New Orleans Sugar we quote 7 ½ @8 cents; Cuba 7 ½ @ 8½ cents; Porto Rico 8@9½ cents; Loaf 11@11 ¼ cents; Crushed and Powdered 10 ¼ cents; Coffee Sugar: A 10 cents; B 9 ½ cents; Extra C 9 ¼ c.
Molasses.--New Orleans 45 cts.; Cuba Muscovado, in bbls., 33@37½ cts.; in hhds., 25@30 cts.; English Island 37½ cts.; Ochenhousen's 28 cts.
Whiskey.--Richmond Rectified 21½ @22½ cents; Stearns' Old Malted Rye $1.50; other qualities 75 cts.;@$1.50 per gallon.

div4.head: Cattle, Hogs, Sheep, &c.
div4.p:
Beef.--Sales this week at $3@4.25 for good to prime cattle.
A very few bought at the latter price.
Market well supplied.
Sheep.--We quote sales at $2.50 to $3 per head for ordinary sheep, and $4.50 to $5 per cwt. gross for the best quality.
Hogs.--Sales of corn-fed at $8@8.50 per cwt.; distillery-fed $7.50@8.

div4.head: Money matters.
div4.p: We give below the best quotations we can obtain:

Exchange on the North is scarce and rates lower.
We quote on New York 5 ¼ Philadelphia 5¼ and Baltimore 4 ½ per cent. premium.

North and South Carolina Bank notes 2@2 ½ per cent. discount.
Planters' and Miners' Bank of Murphy (N. C.) 20 per cent. discount.
Specie 4 ½ @5 per cent. premium.

div3.head: Remember
div3.p:
--Uncurrent money of every State in the Union received at par for Dry Goods of every description, for prices reduced to suit the present great monetary and political crisis.
The panic at hand must be met. I am, therefore, disposed to offer the whole of my valuable stock of Dry Goods at any price from the original cost for cash only.
Recollect, I have no price for any goods in my valuable stock in exchange for specie or uncurrent Bank notes.
My friends and customers would do well to avail themselves of this opportunity to buy some of the cheapest Dry Goods ever offered in the State of Virginia.
Call at the House of Trade at Alfred Moses', 63 Main street.

div3.head: Watt's Cuff-Brace Plows.--Geo. Watt & Co.--established in 1846.
div3.p: --George Watt has obtained, at different times, four separate patents on his Cuff-Brace Plows, acknowledged to embrace the most reliable improvements ever made on this implement, three of which patents have to run respectively ten, twelve and thirteen years, and has been awarded at the late Mechanics' Fair in Richmond a certificate of Silver Medal, for continued superiority in Ploughs, (the highest premiums given,) and at the last State Fair premium on the same, in addition to premiums awarded at all the preceding Fairs for years.

Within two months past he has added other valuable improvements, and we now invited all in want of Plows, warranted in every respect superior to others, to call and examine our large and varied stock of Plows, Castings and Agricultural Implements, and fresh and prime Garden and Field Seed; &c., which we offer for sale on our usual accommondating terms.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --Captains of Volunteer Companies throughout the State are respectfully informed that the Commissioners appointed by law for the purpose of obtaining Accountrements, &c., have made contracts for these items, and as fast as they are delivered at this post they are issued immediately, according to priority of date of orders.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --Volunteer Officers of the State are respectfully informed that beside the bonds required by law, there must be an order from the Adjutant General, to authorize the Superintendent of the State Armory to issue arms, &c.

div3.head:
Bellevue Hospital,
Church Hill, Richmond, Va.
div3.p: White Patihnts--In vards, $5 per week; in private rooms, $7 to $15 per week.

Slaves--$5 per week.
Less than a week, $1 per day; buy not to exceed $5 per week.
Fractions over the first week 71 cents per day.

No extra charges except for surgical oporations, and then an additional fee ranging from $2 to $30, will be charged.
Rills payable on the removal of the patient. No small-pox admitted.

A covered spring wagon will convey patients to and from the Hospital when desired.
Orders may be left at the Hospital, or at the office of A. L. Holiday, 12th street, between Main and Cary.

The subscriber, who has been connected with the institution since its foundation, having taken it under his exclusive charge, aided by competent assistants, solicits a continuance of the liberal patronage of his friends and of the public generally.
Attending Physician and Surgeon.

div3.head: Main St. Hospital for Slaves.
div3.p:
--This Hospital is situated near the corner of Main and 26th streets, and is admirably adapted in airiness, privacy and healthfulness of position, to the purposes for which it has been instituted, namely: For Medical, Surgical and Obstetrical treatment of Slaves.
The rules and regulations governing this institution have already been published.
A circular containing full particulars will be furnished those who may desire further information.

Terms.--Patients per week, $5; less than a week, $1 per diem: but the aggregate shall not exceed the charged for a full week. Patients attending the daily examinations (not fit subjects for Hospital Confinement,) charged the regular fee adopted by the profession at large.
The above charges include board, medicine, medical attendance and nursing.
Surgical operations charged according to rules of other Hospitals of the city.
for further information, apply to the Physician residentat the Hospital, or to either of the undersigned Physicians and Proprietors.

--We make it a rule to keep at all times, fresh, reliable, and fashionable Clothing, and hence to carry over as little as possible from one season to another.
We therefore propose, for the next thirty-days, to offer such inducements in all kinds of Winter Clothing as will ensure sales.
Many styles must be sold without regard to cost.

div3.head: Notice this.
div3.p:

div3.head: Travelers' Guide.
div3.p: Richmond and York River Rail-Road & Steam Boat Line.--Steamer West Point, Capt. J. C. Rowe, leaves Norfolk Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, at 8 A. M., for King & Queen Court-House, connecting with Cars at West Point, at 2 P. M., and arrive in Richmond at 3.30 P. M. Returning, the Steamer leaves King & Queen Court-House on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, at 8.30 A. M., connecting with Cars at West Point at 9.45 A. M., and arrive in Norfolk at 3.30 P. M.
Passenger Traine leave Richmond Daily, (Sunday excepted,) at 8 A. M., and West Point on Tuesday, Thursdays and Saturdays, at 10 A. M., and arrive in Richmond at 11.45 A. M.
Accommodation and Freight Train will leave Richmond Tuesday, Thursdays and Saturdays, at 4 P. M., stopping on signal.
Freight received Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, until 3.30 P. M., at Richmond, and on Mondays, Wednesdays and Friday's, until 2 P. M., at West Point.
Passengers for Williamsburg will take Stage at Bigler's, for Gloucester C. H., at Cappahoosic, and for Saluda and Urbana, at West Point.
Fare from Richmond to Norfolk, (Dinner extra,) $2.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
to Passenger's 1861.
Going North.--New Arrangement.--important to Travellers. --through Tickets and through Checks.--great Northern route — Carrying the great United States Mail.
Twice daily, (Sunday night excepted) between Richmond, alexandria, Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia, New York, and all important points West, via Acquia Creek and Washington, over the Richmond, Frederickburg & Potomac Railroad, to the Potomac river, 75 miles, and by splendid and comfortable steamers thence to Washington, 55 miles--in all 153 miles in seven hours, being a comfortable and perfectly sale rate of speed.
Hours of departure: 6.30 A. M., and 7 P. M.
Baggage, under charge of Special Agents, Checked through to Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New York.

Through Tickets can be secured to the following points, viz: Baltimore, Philadelphia, Cincinati, Columbus, Indianapolis, Cairo, Dayton, Jeffersonville, Rock Island, Zanesville, Washington, New York, St. Louis, Chicago, Pittsburg, Louisville, Decatur, Newark and Vincennes.
Passengers breakfast and sup at Ashland, and dine on board the comfortable steamer between Acquia Creek and Washington.

Persons wishing to obtain tickets for servants for Washington city and points further North, must, in all cases, be vouched for by some responsible white citizen of Richmond, in person, known to the officers of the Road, as no Tickets will be sold if applied for by them.
For further information, apply at this office, Broad Street, Shockoe Hill.

closer.signed: Jas. B. Winston, Gen'l Ticket Ag't.

div3.head: Travelers to the North.--1861.northern Central Railware.
div3.p: --Trains leave Calvert Station, Baltimore, daily, (except Sunday,) at 8.30 A. M., and at 5.30 P. M., for Niagara Falls, (fare only ten dollars,) Buffalo, Owego, Oswego, Toronto, Hamilton, all parts of Western New York and Canada, for Detroit, Chicago, cincinati, St. Louis , and all parts of the West, Northwest and Southwest.
Travelers can go to Detroil, Chicago, Milwankie, &c., via Niagara Falls, at the same cost as by any other route.

A new route to New York is now open by this Road, via Harrisburg and Jersey City, with only on change of cars, Fare, $6. Take the 8.30 A. M. train and go through by daylight, over first-class Roads and through a beautiful country.
Try it.
Buy tickets only to Baltimore.
div3.closer:
Jas. C. Clarke, Sup't.
John T. Rigney, Assistant Sup't. je 13--1y

div3.head: Notice to the public New and important Arrangement, 1861.
div3.p: --The Adams Express Company respectfully announce to the public that they have arranged to run their Express Twice Daily from New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore to Richmond, thereby affording unusual facilities for obtaining their freight and packages in the shortest possible time.

Express leave New York at 1, 5 and 6 o'clock P. M. Expresses leave Philadelphia at 8 A. M., and 11 P. M. Expresses leave Baltimore at 4.20 A. M. and 4.20 P. M., arriving in Richmond at 3.30 A. M. and 2 P. M.
Expresses leave Richmond for New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore, and all points North and West at 6.30 A. M. and 6.30 P. M.
Freight and packages should in all cases be at our office one hour before the departurn of the Trains.
Expresses for the South leave Richmond Twice Daily, at 4.30 A. M., 2.45 P. M.

The Adams Express Company feel that they can guarantee to the public civility, attention and satisfaction in all their intercourse with their officers in Richmond, and nothing will be left undone on their part to meet the wants of their customers.

Freighland packages arriving by the Express from the North at 3 o'clock P. M., will be delivered immediately, thereby giving to our customers and advance of twelve hours over our arrangements heretofore.

Steamer Expresses, to and from New York, Semi-Weekly.
Freights delivered immediately upon the arrival of the ship.
Heavy and Light Freights, packages, money, Bonds, Legal Documents, &c., forwarded with safely and dispatch to all parts of the United States, Canadas, and Europe.
notes, Drafts and bills, with or without Goods, collected at all accessible points throughout the United States, and prompt returns guaranteed.
Slaves forwarded by each of our Expresses, in charge of careful and reliable messengers.
Tobacco and other samples carried at unusually low rates.
All freights promptly called for and delivered without extra charge.
For further information, please call at our office, 202 Main street.
"Adams Ekpress Company,"
